article:
Utopia (Travis Scott album)

Utopia is the fourth studio album by American rapper Travis Scott, released on July 28, 2023, through Epic Records, Cactus Jack Records, and Wicked Awesome Records. The album marks Scott's first studio release since the 2018 album Astroworld.

# Background and recording

The recording process for Utopia began in 2020, with Scott working on the album during the COVID-19 pandemic. In an interview with Rolling Stone, Scott revealed that he had written over 100 songs for the album, but ultimately narrowed it down to 19 tracks. The album features production from a variety of producers, including Boi-1da, Hit-Boy, and Mike Dean, among others.

Scott has stated that the album is inspired by his own personal experiences and observations of the world around him. In an interview with Vogue, Scott explained that the title "Utopia" represents a sense of escapism and fantasy, saying "I'm trying to create a world where people can escape and be free."

# Release and promotion

Utopia was officially announced on July 14, 2023, with Scott releasing a trailer for the album on his social media accounts. The trailer featured a montage of footage from Scott's music videos and live performances, set to a snippet of the album's lead single, "Escape Plan".

The album was released on July 28, 2023, through various music streaming platforms, including Spotify, Apple Music, and Tidal. Scott also released a limited-edition physical edition of the album, which included a bonus track and exclusive artwork.

In the lead-up to the album's release, Scott embarked on a promotional campaign that included a series of pop-up events and concerts. On July 25, 2023, Scott performed a surprise concert at the iconic Coney Island amusement park in Brooklyn, New York, which was livestreamed on YouTube.

# Live events

To support the release of Utopia, Scott announced a series of live events and concerts, including a headlining performance at the 2023 Rolling Loud festival. Scott also performed at a number of music festivals, including the 2023 Governors Ball and the 2023 Lollapalooza.

On August 10, 2023, Scott kicked off his "Utopia World Tour", which featured stops in North America, Europe, and Australia. The tour was met with widespread critical acclaim, with many praising Scott's high-energy performances and elaborate stage production.

# Songs

Utopia features 19 tracks, including the lead single "Escape Plan" and the promotional single "Meltdown". The album also includes guest appearances from a number of high-profile artists, including The Weeknd, Kanye West, and Playboi Carti.

The album's lead single, "Escape Plan", was released on July 21, 2023, and features production from Boi-1da and Jahaan Sweet. The song's music video, which was directed by Scott himself, premiered on YouTube on July 25, 2023.

Other notable tracks on the album include "Parasite", which features a guest appearance from The Weeknd, and "Lost Forever", which features production from Hit-Boy and Mike Dean.

# Critical reception

Utopia received widespread critical acclaim upon its release, with many praising Scott's innovative production and lyrical depth. On Metacritic, the album has a score of 84 out of 100, based on 22 reviews.

Rolling Stone praised the album, saying "Utopia is a bold, boundary-pushing album that showcases Scott's innovative production and lyrical depth." The New York Times also praised the album, saying "Utopia is a thrilling, forward-thinking album that solidifies Scott's status as one of the most exciting young rappers in the game."

## Year-end lists

Utopia appeared on a number of year-end lists, including Rolling Stone's "50 Best Albums of 2023" and Pitchfork's "The 50 Best Albums of 2023".

## Industry awards

Utopia was nominated for a number of industry awards, including the 2024 Grammy Award for Best Rap Album.

# Commercial performance

Utopia debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart, with first-week sales of over 300,000 units. The album also debuted at number one on the UK Albums Chart, with first-week sales of over 20,000 units.

The album's lead single, "Escape Plan", peaked at number two on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart, and was certified platinum by the RIAA.

article:
2022 Tour de France

The 2022 Tour de France was the 109th edition of the Tour de France, one of the most prestigious and highly anticipated events in the world of professional cycling. The tournament took place from July 1 to July 24, 2022, and covered a total distance of approximately 3,328 kilometers. The event was won by Jonas Vingegaard of Denmark, who rode for Team Jumbo-Visma.

# Teams

The 2022 Tour de France featured a total of 22 teams, each consisting of eight riders. The teams were a mix of WorldTeam and ProTeam members, with some notable teams including Team Jumbo-Visma, Ineos Grenadiers, and UAE Team Emirates. The participating teams were:

* AG2R Citroën Team
* Astana Qazaqstan Team
* Bahrain - Victorious
* Bora - Hansgrohe
* Cofidis
* EF Education-EasyPost
* Groupama - FDJ
* Ineos Grenadiers
* Intermarché - Wanty - Gobert Matériaux
* Israel - Premier Tech
* Lotto Soudal
* Movistar Team
* Quick-Step Alpha Vinyl Team
* Team BikeExchange - Jayco
* Team DSM
* Team Jumbo-Visma
* Team TotalEnergies
* Trek - Segafredo
* UAE Team Emirates
* Arkéa - Samsic
* B&B Hotels - KTM
* Team TotalEnergies

# Route and stages

The 2022 Tour de France route was announced in October 2021 and featured a total of 21 stages, including two individual time trials and seven mountain stages. The route took the riders through several regions of France, as well as neighboring countries such as Denmark, Belgium, and Switzerland. The stages were designed to be challenging and varied, with a mix of flat, hilly, and mountainous terrain.

The route began in Copenhagen, Denmark, with a 13.2-kilometer individual time trial and ended in Paris, France, with a traditional circuit around the Champs-Élysées. The mountain stages took place in the Alps and the Pyrenees, with notable climbs such as the Col du Galibier, the Col de la Croix-Fry, and the Hautacam.

# Pre-race favourites

The pre-race favourites for the 2022 Tour de France included several top riders, each with their own strengths and weaknesses. Some of the most notable favourites included:

* Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates): The defending champion and one of the most dominant riders in the world.
* Jonas Vingegaard (Team Jumbo-Visma): A strong climber and time-trialist, who had a breakout season in 2021.
* Primoz Roglic (Team Jumbo-Visma): A multiple-time Grand Tour winner, who had a strong team behind him.
* Geraint Thomas (Ineos Grenadiers): A former Tour de France winner, who had shown good form in the lead-up to the event.
* Nairo Quintana (Arkéa - Samsic): A multiple-time Grand Tour winner, who had a strong team behind him.

# Race overview

## Grand Départ and Week One

The 2022 Tour de France began in Copenhagen, Denmark, with a 13.2-kilometer individual time trial. The stage was won by Yves Lampaert (Quick-Step Alpha Vinyl Team), who took the first yellow jersey of the event. The first week of the tour took the riders through Denmark and into France, with a mix of flat and hilly stages.

The early stages saw several crashes and mechanical issues, which affected some of the top riders. Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates) was one of the riders affected, losing several minutes due to a mechanical issue on stage 5.

## Week Two

The second week of the tour took the riders into the Alps, with several mountain stages. The stage 7 was won by Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates), who took the yellow jersey and became the new leader of the general classification.

However, Pogačar's lead was short-lived, as he lost several minutes on stage 11 due to a mechanical issue and a crash. Jonas Vingegaard (Team Jumbo-Visma) took advantage of Pogačar's misfortune and took the yellow jersey.

## Week Three

The final week of the tour took the riders into the Pyrenees, with several mountain stages. The stage 17 was won by Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates), who tried to claw back time from Jonas Vingegaard (Team Jumbo-Visma).

However, Vingegaard's lead was too big, and he held on to win the general classification. Pogačar finished second, while Geraint Thomas (Ineos Grenadiers) finished third.

# Classification leadership

* General classification: Yves Lampaert (Quick-Step Alpha Vinyl Team) (stage 1), Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates) (stages 7-10), Jonas Vingegaard (Team Jumbo-Visma) (stages 11-21)
* Points classification: Wout van Aert (Team Jumbo-Visma) (stages 1-21)
* Mountains classification: Simon Geschke (Cofidis) (stages 1-5), Alexis Vuillermoz (Team TotalEnergies) (stages 6-8), Simon Geschke (Cofidis) (stages 9-21)
* Young rider classification: Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates) (stages 1-10), Tom Pidcock (Ineos Grenadiers) (stages 11-21)
* Team classification: Ineos Grenadiers (stages 1-2), EF Education-EasyPost (stages 3-5), Ineos Grenadiers (stages 6-21)

# Final classification standings

## General classification

1. Jonas Vingegaard (Team Jumbo-Visma) - 79h 33' 20"
2. Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates) - +2' 43"
3. Geraint Thomas (Ineos Grenadiers) - +7' 22"
4. Nairo Quintana (Arkéa - Samsic) - +13' 2"
5. David Gaudu (Groupama - FDJ) - +13' 39"

# Notes

* The 2022 Tour de France was the first edition of the event to feature a stage in Denmark.
* The event was won by Jonas Vingegaard, who became the first Danish rider to win the Tour de France.
* Tadej Pogačar (UAE Team Emirates) won the young rider classification for the third consecutive year.

Algeria at the 2022 Mediterranean Games

The 2022 Mediterranean Games, officially known as the XIX Mediterranean Games, was a multi-sport event held in Oran, Algeria, from June 25 to July 6, 2022. Algeria was the host country for the Games, which brought together athletes from 26 Mediterranean nations. This article provides an overview of Algeria's participation in the 2022 Mediterranean Games.

# Medal summary

## Medal table

Algeria won a total of 53 medals during the 2022 Mediterranean Games, consisting of 20 gold medals, 17 silver medals, and 16 bronze medals. The country finished second in the overall medal table, behind Italy.

# Archery

Algeria entered a team of four archers in the 2022 Mediterranean Games, competing in both individual and team events. In the men's individual event, Algerian archer Mohamed Hammed finished in 17th place, while his compatriot Kaouther Laouadi finished 10th in the women's individual event. The Algerian men's team finished 5th in the team event, while the women's team finished 6th.

article:
Javier Milei

Javier Gerardo Milei (born 12 October 1970) is an Argentine economist, journalist, and politician who has been serving as the President of Argentina since 2023. A member of the Libertarian party, La Libertad Avanza, he won the 2023 Argentine general election, defeating Sergio Massa in the general election.

#Early life and education

Milei was born in Buenos Aires, Argentina, on 12 October 1970. He grew up in a middle-class family and was raised in the neighborhood of Palermo. His parents were both entrepreneurs, and his father owned a small business. Milei has two siblings, and his family was known for their strong conservative values.

Milei attended the Instituto San Ignacio de Loyola, a private Catholic school in Buenos Aires. After completing his secondary education, he enrolled in the Universidad del CEMA (UCEMA), where he studied economics. During his time at university, Milei became interested in libertarian ideology and began to read the works of authors such as Friedrich Hayek and Milton Friedman.

#Economics career

After graduating from university, Milei began his career as an economist. He worked as a researcher at the Fundación de Investigaciones Económicas Latinoamericanas (FIEL), a think tank based in Buenos Aires. During his time at FIEL, Milei published numerous articles and papers on economic policy and development.

In 2001, Milei joined the Argentine Central Bank as an economist. He worked in the bank's research department, where he analyzed economic data and developed policy recommendations. Milei's work at the Central Bank focused on monetary policy and inflation control.

#Early political career

Milei's interest in politics began during his time at university. He was a member of the libertarian student organization, Grupo de Estudiantes Libertarios (GEL). After graduating, Milei continued to be involved in libertarian activism, attending conferences and events.

##Rise to prominence

Milei's rise to prominence began in 2016, when he started hosting a radio show, "El primero de la mañana" (The first of the morning), on the Argentine radio station, Radio Mitre. The show focused on economic and political analysis, and quickly gained a large following.

##2021 legislative campaign

In 2021, Milei announced his candidacy for the Argentine Chamber of Deputies. He ran as a member of the Libertarian party, La Libertad Avanza, and won a seat in the Chamber, representing the city of Buenos Aires.

#National deputyship

As a national deputy, Milei focused on economic policy and development. He was a member of the Chamber's economics committee and advocated for policies such as tax reform and deregulation.

#2023 Argentine general election

##2023 presidential campaign

In 2023, Milei announced his candidacy for the presidency of Argentina. He ran as a member of La Libertad Avanza and won the party's primary election.

##Primary and general elections

Milei won the general election, defeating Sergio Massa in a runoff. His victory was seen as a surprise by many, as he was a relatively unknown candidate outside of libertarian circles.

#Presidency (2023–present)

##Inauguration

Milei was inaugurated as President of Argentina on 10 December 2023. His inauguration was attended by dignitaries from around the world and marked the beginning of his presidency.

##First acts

Milei's first acts as president focused on economic policy. He announced a series of reforms aimed at reducing inflation and promoting economic growth.

##Economy

Milei's economic policy has been characterized as libertarian and free-market oriented. He has advocated for policies such as tax reform, deregulation, and privatization.

#Political positions

Milei's political positions are generally considered to be libertarian and conservative. He has advocated for policies such as:

* Tax reform and reduction
* Deregulation and privatization
* Free trade and globalization
* Limited government and individual freedom
* Strong national defense

#Public image

Milei's public image is that of a charismatic and confident leader. He is known for his strong personality and his ability to connect with voters.

#Personal life

Milei is married to a woman named Cecilia and has two children. He is a practicing Catholic and has spoken publicly about the importance of his faith.

#Electoral history

##Executive

* 2023 Argentine general election: President of Argentina (won)

##Legislative

* 2021 Argentine legislative election: National Deputy for the city of Buenos Aires (won)

#Radio

Milei has hosted several radio shows, including:

* "El primero de la mañana" (The first of the morning) on Radio Mitre

#Publications

##Books

Milei has written several books on economics and politics, including:

* "La crisis argentina" (The Argentine crisis)
* "El futuro de la economía" (The future of the economy)

##Journal articles

Milei has published numerous articles in academic journals and newspapers, including:

* "La reforma tributaria en Argentina" (Tax reform in Argentina) in the Journal of Economic Policy
* "El impacto de la inflación en la economía argentina" (The impact of inflation on the Argentine economy) in the Buenos Aires Herald

article:
Indeterminacy Debate in Legal Theory

The indeterminacy debate in legal theory is a longstanding controversy among legal scholars, philosophers, and theorists about the nature and limits of legal interpretation. At its core, the debate centers on the question of whether the meaning of laws and legal texts is determinate or indeterminate. This article provides an overview of the indeterminacy debate, its key arguments, and the implications for legal theory and practice.

# Introduction

The indeterminacy debate in legal theory has its roots in the early 20th century, when legal scholars began to question the notion of objective interpretation of laws. The debate gained momentum in the 1980s with the publication of several influential works, including those by Ronald Dworkin, Stanley Fish, and Duncan Kennedy. Since then, the debate has continued to evolve, with new arguments and perspectives emerging from various fields, including philosophy, linguistics, and sociology.

## The Challenge of Indeterminacy

The indeterminacy debate is premised on the idea that the meaning of laws and legal texts is not fixed or determinate. Instead, the meaning is subject to multiple interpretations, and the outcome of any given case is uncertain. This uncertainty arises from several sources, including the ambiguity of language, the complexity of social and cultural contexts, and the subjective perspectives of judges and lawyers.

## Determinacy and Objectivity

Proponents of determinacy argue that the meaning of laws and legal texts can be determined through objective interpretation. According to this view, the meaning of a law is fixed at the time of its creation and can be discovered through careful analysis of the text, its legislative history, and the intentions of its drafters. Determinacy is often seen as essential to the rule of law, as it provides a basis for predictable and consistent application of laws.

## Indeterminacy and Subjectivity

In contrast, proponents of indeterminacy argue that the meaning of laws and legal texts is inherently subjective and context-dependent. According to this view, the meaning of a law is not fixed and can be interpreted in multiple ways, depending on the perspectives and values of the interpreter. Indeterminacy is often seen as a necessary consequence of the complexity and ambiguity of human language and social reality.

## Critiques of Determinacy

Critics of determinacy argue that the idea of objective interpretation is unrealistic and ignores the complexities of human language and social context. They point out that laws and legal texts are often ambiguous, vague, or open-ended, leaving room for multiple interpretations. Moreover, the intentions of lawmakers and the legislative history of a law can be unclear or contested, making it difficult to determine the "true" meaning of a law.

## Critiques of Indeterminacy

Critics of indeterminacy argue that the idea of subjective interpretation undermines the rule of law and leads to arbitrary and unpredictable application of laws. They point out that indeterminacy can result in conflicting interpretations and inconsistent application of laws, which can erode public trust in the legal system. Moreover, indeterminacy can be exploited by powerful interests to manipulate the interpretation of laws for their own benefit.

## Implications for Legal Theory

The indeterminacy debate has significant implications for legal theory and practice. If the meaning of laws and legal texts is indeterminate, then the traditional notion of objective interpretation must be revised. This may require new approaches to legal interpretation, such as a more nuanced understanding of the role of context, culture, and power in shaping the meaning of laws. Alternatively, if the meaning of laws and legal texts is determinate, then the traditional notion of objective interpretation must be defended against the challenges of indeterminacy.

## Implications for Legal Practice

The indeterminacy debate also has significant implications for legal practice. If the meaning of laws and legal texts is indeterminate, then lawyers and judges must be more aware of the complexities and nuances of legal interpretation. This may require new skills and strategies for navigating the ambiguities and uncertainties of the law. Alternatively, if the meaning of laws and legal texts is determinate, then lawyers and judges must be more careful in their application of the law, to ensure that the "true" meaning of the law is respected.

# See also

* Critical legal studies
* Law and economics
* Legal positivism
* Natural law
* Postmodernism and law
* Rule of law

article:
Ms. Marvel (miniseries)

Ms. Marvel is a 2022 American television miniseries created by Bisha K. Ali for the streaming service Disney+. Based on the Marvel Comics character Kamala Khan / Ms. Marvel, it is the seventh television series in the Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU) produced by Marvel Studios. The miniseries follows the story of Kamala Khan, a teenage Pakistani-American girl who gains superpowers and becomes the superhero Ms. Marvel.

# Premise

The miniseries explores the life of Kamala Khan, a 16-year-old high school student from Jersey City, New Jersey. Kamala is a huge fan of the Avengers, particularly Captain Marvel, and spends most of her free time creating fan art and writing fan fiction about her idol. She is also a Pakistani-American Muslim, and the series explores the challenges she faces in balancing her cultural identity with her love for superhero culture. When Kamala discovers a mysterious bangle that grants her superpowers, she becomes the superhero Ms. Marvel, using her newfound abilities to protect her community and fight against evil.

# Cast and characters

* Iman Vellani as Kamala Khan / Ms. Marvel: A 16-year-old high school student who becomes the superhero Ms. Marvel.
* Aramis Knight as Kareem / Red Dagger: A vigilante from Pakistan who becomes an ally to Kamala.
* Saagar Shaikh as Amir Khan: Kamala's older brother who is often at odds with their parents.
* Rish Shah as Kamran: A charming and popular boy at Kamala's school who becomes her love interest.
* Zenobia Shroff as Muneeba Khan: Kamala's mother who is often at odds with her daughter's choices.
* Mohan Kapur as Yusuf Khan: Kamala's father who is more laid-back and supportive of his daughter's decisions.
* Matt Lintz as Bruno Carrelli: Kamala's best friend and confidant who helps her with her superhero alter ego.
* Yasmeen Fletcher as Nakia Bahadir: A popular girl at Kamala's school who becomes an ally to her.
* Laith Nakli as Sheikh Abdullah: A Muslim leader in Kamala's community who becomes a source of guidance for her.

# Episodes

The miniseries consists of six episodes, each with a runtime of approximately 40-50 minutes.

1. "Generation Why"
2. "Crushed"
3. "Destined"
4. "Seeing Red"
5. "Time and Again"
6. "No Normal"

# Production

## Development

Marvel Studios began developing a television series based on Ms. Marvel in 2019, with Bisha K. Ali serving as the head writer and showrunner. The miniseries was announced in November 2019, with Iman Vellani cast as Kamala Khan / Ms. Marvel in September 2020.

## Writing

The writing team for the miniseries consisted of Bisha K. Ali, A.C. Bradley, Matthew Chauncey, and Fatimah Asghar, among others. The team drew inspiration from the Marvel Comics character Kamala Khan, as well as the experiences of Pakistani-American Muslims.

## Casting

Iman Vellani was cast as Kamala Khan / Ms. Marvel in September 2020, after a lengthy audition process. The rest of the cast, including Aramis Knight, Saagar Shaikh, and Rish Shah, were cast in the following months.

## Design

The miniseries features a blend of traditional Pakistani and American cultures, with a vibrant color palette and intricate costumes. The production design team, led by Dan DeLeeuw, drew inspiration from the streets of Jersey City and the traditions of Pakistani-American Muslims.

## Filming

Principal photography began in November 2020 in Atlanta, Georgia, and lasted for approximately six months. The miniseries was filmed on location in Jersey City, New Jersey, as well as in Pakistan.

## Post-production

The post-production team, led by editors Nona Khodai and Sabrina Plisco, worked to bring the miniseries to life, incorporating visual effects and music into the final product.

## Music

The miniseries features a blend of traditional Pakistani and American music, with a score composed by Laura Karpman. The soundtrack includes songs by Pakistani artists such as Atif Aslam and Rahat Fateh Ali Khan.

# Marketing

The marketing campaign for the miniseries began in May 2022, with the release of a teaser trailer. The campaign included promotional posters, social media posts, and interviews with the cast and crew.

# Release

The miniseries was released on Disney+ on June 8, 2022, with new episodes released weekly.

# Reception

## Viewership

The miniseries was watched by millions of viewers worldwide, with the first episode attracting a large audience.

## Critical response

The miniseries received widespread critical acclaim, with praise for its representation, writing, and performances. Reviewers praised the miniseries for its authentic portrayal of Pakistani-American Muslims and its exploration of themes such as identity and culture.

## Accolades

The miniseries received several award nominations, including a Primetime Emmy Award nomination for Outstanding Limited or Anthology Series.

# Documentary special

A documentary special, "Assembled: The Making of Ms. Marvel," was released on Disney+ in July 2022, offering a behind-the-scenes look at the making of the miniseries.

# Future

In July 2022, Marvel Studios announced that a second season of the miniseries was in development, with Bisha K. Ali returning as showrunner.

# Notes

The miniseries marks the first time a Pakistani-American Muslim superhero has been featured in a live-action television series.

article:
Crown Jewel (2022)

Crown Jewel was a professional wrestling event produced by WWE, a global entertainment company. It took place on November 5, 2022, at Mrsool Park in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The event was the fourth edition of Crown Jewel and featured wrestlers from the Raw and SmackDown brands.

# Production

## Background

In 2018, WWE signed a 10-year agreement with the Saudi Arabian government to host recurring events in the country. The deal was part of Saudi Arabia's Vision 2030 plan to diversify its economy and improve its global reputation. Crown Jewel was one of the events created as a result of this partnership.

## Iranian attack concerns

In the weeks leading up to the event, there were concerns about a potential Iranian-backed attack on the WWE's Crown Jewel event in Saudi Arabia. The concerns were raised due to the increasing tensions between Iran and Saudi Arabia, as well as the recent attacks on Saudi oil facilities. However, the event went ahead as scheduled without any incidents.

## Storylines

The event featured several matches, including a main event match between Roman Reigns and Logan Paul for the Undisputed WWE Universal Championship.

### Main event match

The main event match was between Roman Reigns and Logan Paul for the Undisputed WWE Universal Championship. The match was a highly anticipated bout, with Reigns being the reigning champion and Paul being a social media personality making his in-ring debut. The match was built up over the preceding weeks, with Paul and Reigns engaging in a series of verbal exchanges and physical confrontations.

### Undercard matches

In addition to the main event match, the event also featured several undercard matches. These included a steel cage match between Drew McIntyre and Karrion Kross, a six-man tag team match between The Judgment Day and The O.C., and a match between Braun Strowman and Omos.

# Event

## Preliminary matches

The event began with a series of preliminary matches. The first match was between The Usos and The Brawling Brutes, which The Usos won. The next match was between The Street Profits and Alpha Academy, which The Street Profits won.

## Main event

The main event match between Roman Reigns and Logan Paul for the Undisputed WWE Universal Championship was a highly intense and physical bout. The match saw both men exchange blows and near-falls, with Paul surprising many by holding his own against the reigning champion. However, in the end, Reigns emerged victorious, pinning Paul to retain the title.

# Reception

The event received generally positive reviews from fans and critics alike. Many praised the matches, particularly the main event match between Reigns and Paul. The event was also a commercial success, with WWE reporting a significant increase in revenue from the event.

# Aftermath

## Raw

article:
2023 NBA Finals

The 2023 NBA Finals was the championship series of the 2022-2023 National Basketball Association (NBA) season. The series featured the Miami Heat from the Eastern Conference and the Denver Nuggets from the Western Conference. The Nuggets won the series 4-1, capturing their first NBA championship in franchise history.

#Background

##Miami Heat

The Miami Heat entered the 2022-2023 season with high expectations after a strong playoff run the previous year. Led by veterans Jimmy Butler and Bam Adebayo, the Heat looked to make a deep postseason run. However, the team faced several challenges, including injuries to key players and inconsistent team chemistry. Despite these issues, the Heat managed to secure the 8th seed in the Eastern Conference playoffs.

##Denver Nuggets

The Denver Nuggets entered the 2022-2023 season as one of the top contenders in the Western Conference. Led by reigning MVP Nikola Jokić, the Nuggets boasted a deep and talented roster. The team made several key additions in the offseason, including the signing of free agent Kentavious Caldwell-Pope. With a strong regular season performance, the Nuggets secured the 1st seed in the Western Conference playoffs.

##Road to the Finals

The Miami Heat began their playoff run in the play-in tournament, where they defeated the Atlanta Hawks to secure the 8th seed in the Eastern Conference. The Heat then upset the top-seeded Milwaukee Bucks in the first round, advancing to the conference semifinals. After defeating the New York Knicks in the semifinals, the Heat advanced to the Eastern Conference Finals, where they defeated the Boston Celtics in seven games.

The Denver Nuggets, on the other hand, had a relatively smooth playoff run. The Nuggets defeated the Minnesota Timberwolves in the first round, advancing to the conference semifinals. After defeating the Phoenix Suns in the semifinals, the Nuggets advanced to the Western Conference Finals, where they defeated the Los Angeles Lakers in five games.

##Regular season series

The Miami Heat and Denver Nuggets met twice during the regular season, with the Nuggets winning both games. The first matchup took place on November 14, 2022, with the Nuggets winning 112-105. The second matchup took place on February 13, 2023, with the Nuggets winning 115-103.

#Series summary

The 2023 NBA Finals began on June 1, 2023, with the Denver Nuggets hosting the Miami Heat at Ball Arena. The series was marked by dominant performances from the Nuggets, who won four of the first five games. The Heat struggled to contain the Nuggets' high-powered offense, led by Nikola Jokić and Jamal Murray. The Nuggets' championship win marked the first in franchise history.

#Game summaries

##Game 1

Game 1 took place on June 1, 2023, at Ball Arena. The Nuggets won the game 123-109, behind a strong performance from Nikola Jokić. Jokić scored 27 points and added 10 rebounds and 14 assists, leading the Nuggets to a dominant win.

##Game 2

Game 2 took place on June 3, 2023, at Ball Arena. The Nuggets won the game 111-95, behind a strong performance from Jamal Murray. Murray scored 28 points and added 5 rebounds and 7 assists, leading the Nuggets to a 2-0 series lead.

##Game 3

Game 3 took place on June 7, 2023, at FTX Arena. The Heat won the game 109-94, behind a strong performance from Jimmy Butler. Butler scored 25 points and added 10 rebounds and 5 assists, leading the Heat to their first win of the series.

##Game 4

Game 4 took place on June 9, 2023, at FTX Arena. The Nuggets won the game 108-95, behind a strong performance from Nikola Jokić. Jokić scored 23 points and added 12 rebounds and 11 assists, leading the Nuggets to a 3-1 series lead.

##Game 5

Game 5 took place on June 12, 2023, at Ball Arena. The Nuggets won the game 94-89, behind a strong performance from Jamal Murray. Murray scored 22 points and added 5 rebounds and 6 assists, leading the Nuggets to their first NBA championship.

#Media coverage

###Viewership

The 2023 NBA Finals averaged 7.56 million viewers per game, making it the most-watched NBA Finals since 2018. Game 5 was the most-watched game of the series, with 10.5 million viewers.

#Aftermath

The Denver Nuggets' championship win marked the first in franchise history. The team celebrated with a parade in downtown Denver, attended by thousands of fans. The Nuggets' victory also marked the first championship won by a team from the Western Conference since 2018.

The Miami Heat, on the other hand, were left to ponder what could have been. Despite a strong playoff run, the Heat were unable to overcome the dominant Nuggets. The Heat will look to regroup and rebuild in the offseason, with the goal of making another deep playoff run in the future.

article:
# History of Rock Climbing

Rock climbing, a physically demanding sport that involves ascending rock formations using various techniques and equipment, has a rich and diverse history that spans thousands of years. From ancient civilizations to modern-day athletes, rock climbing has evolved significantly over time, shaped by advances in technology, changes in societal attitudes, and the contributions of pioneers who pushed the boundaries of what was thought possible.

# Origins

The earliest recorded evidence of rock climbing dates back to ancient civilizations in the Middle East, Africa, and Asia, where people would climb rocks and mountains for spiritual, practical, and recreational purposes. In ancient Greece, for example, rock climbing was considered a form of spiritual asceticism, while in India, the practice of rock climbing was closely tied to Hinduism and the pursuit of enlightenment. Similarly, in Africa, rock climbing was used by indigenous tribes for hunting and gathering, as well as for spiritual and ceremonial purposes.

## Early Climbing Techniques

The earliest rock climbing techniques were relatively simple, involving the use of hands, feet, and basic tools such as ropes and wooden pegs. Climbers would often use natural features such as cracks, ledges, and chimneys to ascend the rock face, and would rely on their own strength, agility, and balance to overcome obstacles.

# 19th Century

The modern era of rock climbing began to take shape in the 19th century, with the rise of mountaineering and the development of new climbing techniques and equipment. In Europe, the Alps became a popular destination for climbers, who were drawn to the region's rugged terrain and breathtaking scenery. The first ascents of many of the Alps' most iconic peaks, including the Matterhorn and the Eiger, took place during this period.

## The Golden Age of Mountaineering

The late 19th century is often referred to as the "Golden Age of Mountaineering," a period of rapid progress and innovation in the sport. Climbers such as Albert Smith and Edward Whymper pioneered new routes and techniques, and the development of the first climbing clubs and organizations helped to promote the sport and establish a sense of community among climbers.

# 1900s

The early 20th century saw significant advances in rock climbing technology, including the development of new types of rope, harnesses, and other equipment. Climbers such as Walter Amstutz and Alfred Couttet pushed the boundaries of what was possible, making the first ascents of many of the Alps' most challenging peaks.

## The Rise of Sport Climbing

The 1900s also saw the emergence of sport climbing, a style of climbing that emphasizes speed, efficiency, and technique. Sport climbers such as Pierre Allain and René Desmaison pioneered new routes and techniques, and the development of the first climbing gyms and training facilities helped to promote the sport and establish a sense of community among climbers.

# 1910s

The 1910s were marked by significant progress in rock climbing, with the first ascents of many of the Alps' most iconic peaks. Climbers such as Arnold Lunn and Geoffrey Winthrop Young pioneered new routes and techniques, and the development of the first climbing clubs and organizations helped to promote the sport and establish a sense of community among climbers.

## The Impact of World War I

The outbreak of World War I had a significant impact on rock climbing, as many of the sport's leading figures were called to serve in the military. The war also led to a decline in climbing activity, as many of the Alps' most popular destinations were closed to climbers.

# 1920s

The 1920s saw a resurgence in rock climbing, as the sport continued to evolve and grow in popularity. Climbers such as Heinrich Harrer and Fritz Kasparek pioneered new routes and techniques, and the development of the first climbing gyms and training facilities helped to promote the sport and establish a sense of community among climbers.

## The Rise of Bouldering

The 1920s also saw the emergence of bouldering, a style of climbing that involves ascending short, low-level rock formations without the use of ropes or other equipment. Bouldering pioneers such as Pierre Allain and René Desmaison developed new techniques and routes, and the sport quickly gained popularity among climbers.

# 1930s

The 1930s were marked by significant progress in rock climbing, with the first ascents of many of the Alps' most iconic peaks. Climbers such as Anderl Heckmair and Ludwig Vörg pioneered new routes and techniques, and the development of the first climbing clubs and organizations helped to promote the sport and establish a sense of community among climbers.

## The Impact of World War II

The outbreak of World War II had a significant impact on rock climbing, as many of the sport's leading figures were called to serve in the military. The war also led to a decline in climbing activity, as many of the Alps' most popular destinations were closed to climbers.

# 1940s

The 1940s saw a decline in rock climbing activity, as the sport was disrupted by the war. However, the decade also saw the emergence of new climbing styles and techniques, including the development of aid climbing and the use of pitons.

## The Rise of Yosemite Climbing

The 1940s also saw the emergence of Yosemite climbing, a style of climbing that emphasizes big wall ascents and the use of aid equipment. Yosemite pioneers such as John Salathé and Yvon Chouinard developed new routes and techniques, and the sport quickly gained popularity among climbers.

# 1950s

The 1950s saw significant progress in rock climbing, with the first ascents of many of the Alps' most iconic peaks. Climbers such as Walter Bonatti and Gaston Rebuffat pioneered new routes and techniques, and the development of the first climbing gyms and training facilities helped to promote the sport and establish a sense of community among climbers.

## The Rise of Free Climbing

The 1950s also saw the emergence of free climbing, a style of climbing that emphasizes the use of only hands, feet, and other body parts to ascend the rock face. Free climbing pioneers such as John Gill and Royal Robbins developed new techniques and routes, and the sport quickly gained popularity among climbers.

# 1960s

The 1960s were marked by significant progress in rock climbing, with the first ascents of many of the Alps' most iconic peaks. Climbers such as Reinhold Messner and Peter Habeler pioneered new routes and techniques, and the development of the first climbing gyms and training facilities helped to promote the sport and establish a sense of community among climbers.

## The Rise of Sport Climbing

The 1960s also saw the emergence of sport climbing as a distinct style of climbing. Sport climbers such as Pierre Allain and René Desmaison developed new routes and techniques, and the sport quickly gained popularity among climbers.

# 1970s

The 1970s saw significant progress in rock climbing, with the first ascents of many of the Alps' most iconic peaks. Climbers such as Doug Scott and Chris Bonington pioneered new routes and techniques, and the development of the first climbing gyms and training facilities helped to promote the sport and establish a sense of community among climbers.

## The Rise of Bouldering

The 1970s also saw the emergence of bouldering as a distinct style of climbing. Bouldering pioneers such as John Gill and Royal Robbins developed new techniques and routes, and the sport quickly gained popularity among climbers.

# 1980s

The 1980s saw significant progress in rock climbing, with the first ascents of many of the Alps' most iconic peaks. Climbers such as Ueli Bühler and Martin Scheel pioneered new routes and techniques, and the development of the first climbing gyms and training facilities helped to promote the sport and establish a sense of community among climbers.

## The Rise of Competitions

The 1980s also saw the emergence of competitions as a major aspect of rock climbing. The first international competitions took place during this decade, and the sport quickly gained popularity among climbers.

# 1990s

The 1990s saw significant progress in rock climbing, with the first ascents of many of the Alps' most iconic peaks. Climbers such as Lynn Hill and Alex Honnold pioneered new routes and techniques, and the development of the first climbing gyms and training facilities helped to promote the sport and establish a sense of community among climbers.

## The Rise of Indoor Climbing

The 1990s also saw the emergence of indoor climbing as a distinct style of climbing. Indoor climbing gyms and training facilities became increasingly popular, and the sport quickly gained popularity among climbers.

# 2000s

The 2000s saw significant progress in rock climbing, with the first ascents of many of the Alps' most iconic peaks. Climbers such as Tommy Caldwell and Beth Rodden pioneered new routes and techniques, and the development of the first climbing gyms and training facilities helped to promote the sport and establish a sense of community among climbers.

## The Rise of Bouldering Competitions

The 2000s also saw the emergence of bouldering competitions as a major aspect of rock climbing. The first international bouldering competitions took place during this decade, and the sport quickly gained popularity among climbers.

# 2010s

The 2010s saw significant progress in rock climbing, with the first ascents of many of the Alps' most iconic peaks. Climbers such as Adam Ondra and Margo Hayes pioneered new routes and techniques, and the development of the first climbing gyms and training facilities helped to promote the sport and establish a sense of community among climbers.

## The Rise of Climbing as an Olympic Sport

The 2010s also saw the emergence of climbing as an Olympic sport. Climbing made its Olympic debut at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics, and the sport quickly gained popularity among climbers.

# 2020s

The 2020s have seen significant progress in rock climbing, with the first ascents of many of the Alps' most iconic peaks. Climbers such as Alex Honnold and Lynn Hill continue to push the boundaries of what is possible, and the development of new climbing gyms and training facilities has helped to promote the sport and establish a sense of community among climbers.

## The Future of Rock Climbing

As rock climbing continues to evolve and grow in popularity, it is likely that the sport will continue to see significant progress and innovation in the years to come. With the rise of new technologies and training methods, climbers will be able to push themselves harder and achieve greater things than ever before.

The event featured ten teams in the men's and women's A divisions, eight teams in the B divisions, and 16 teams in the C divisions. article:
Big Brother Canada Season 11

Big Brother Canada Season 11 was the eleventh season of the Canadian reality television series Big Brother Canada. The season premiered on March 9, 2023, on Global and concluded on May 18, 2023. The show was hosted by Arisa Cox.

# Format

Big Brother Canada Season 11 followed the same format as previous seasons, with a group of contestants, known as "HouseGuests", living together in a custom-built house with cameras and microphones recording their every move. The HouseGuests competed in various challenges and games to win power and prizes, while also voting each other off the show. The last HouseGuest remaining won the grand prize of $100,000.

# HouseGuests

The season featured 16 HouseGuests, including a mix of new and returning players. The HouseGuests were:

1. Adam Pike
2. Alecia Kallos
3. Arissa Cox ( guest appearance)
4. Ben Driebergen
5. Brooke Warnock
6. Claudia Campbell
7. Daniel Clarke
8. Hope Petrow
9. John Luke Kieper
10. Jonathan Leonard
11. Kaela Grant
12. Kevin Jacobs
13. Rohan Kapoor
14. Samantha Picco
15. Santina Carlson
16. Ty McDonald

## Future appearances

Several HouseGuests from Season 11 have gone on to appear in other reality TV shows, including The Challenge and Ex on the Beach.

# Summary

The season began with the introduction of the 16 HouseGuests, who entered the Big Brother Canada house on March 9, 2023. The first Head of Household (HOH) competition was won by Adam Pike, who nominated Alecia Kallos and Hope Petrow for eviction. The first Power of Veto (POV) competition was won by Ben Driebergen, who saved Hope from the block. Alecia was ultimately evicted from the house on March 16, 2023.

Throughout the season, the HouseGuests competed in various challenges and games, including HOH and POV competitions, and voted each other off the show. The season saw several twists, including the introduction of new powers and surprises that shook up the game.

# Episodes

The season consisted of 35 episodes, which aired on Global from March 9 to May 18, 2023. Each episode was approximately 60 minutes long, including commercials.

# Twists

The season featured several twists, including:

## Dead Last Nomination

In this twist, the HouseGuest who came in last place in a competition was automatically nominated for eviction.

## Belairdirect Eviction Protection Insurance

In this twist, HouseGuests could win a chance to save themselves or a fellow HouseGuest from eviction.

## Wendy's Rewards Points

In this twist, HouseGuests could earn rewards points by completing challenges and tasks. These points could be redeemed for prizes and advantages in the game.

## Whodunit Week

In this twist, the HouseGuests were given a mystery to solve, and the winner of the challenge earned a reward.

## Fatal Feast

In this twist, the HouseGuests competed in a series of challenges, with the loser being eliminated from the game.

## Other twists

The season also featured several other twists, including surprise evictions and unexpected powers.

# Production

## Development

The season was developed by Insight Productions, in association with Global and CBS Studios.

## Prizes

The grand prize for the season was $100,000, which was awarded to the last HouseGuest remaining in the game.

## Production design

The Big Brother Canada house was designed by Peter Faragher, and was built in a custom-built facility in Toronto, Ontario.

## Digital Dailies

The season was streamed live on the Big Brother Canada website and mobile app, with exclusive content and behind-the-scenes footage.

# Voting history

The voting history for the season is as follows:

* Week 1: Alecia Kallos ( evicted)
* Week 2: Hope Petrow (evicted)
* Week 3: Daniel Clarke (evicted)
* Week 4: Claudia Campbell (evicted)
* Week 5: Kaela Grant (evicted)
* Week 6: Rohan Kapoor (evicted)
* Week 7: Santina Carlson (evicted)
* Week 8: Ben Driebergen (evicted)
* Week 9: Jonathan Leonard (evicted)
* Week 10: Kevin Jacobs (evicted)
* Week 11: Ty McDonald (evicted)
* Week 12: Samantha Picco (evicted)
* Week 13: Brooke Warnock (evicted)
* Week 14: Adam Pike (winner)

## Notes

* The season featured several tie votes, which were broken by the HOH.
* Several HouseGuests were medically evacuated from the game due to illness or injury.

# Reception

The season received generally positive reviews from critics and fans, with many praising the twists and challenges.

# References

None

# External links

* Big Brother Canada official website
* Global website
* Big Brother Canada on Twitter

2022 Ottawa Municipal Election

The 2022 Ottawa municipal election was held on October 24, 2022, to elect the mayor and city councillors of Ottawa, Ontario, Canada. The election was held in conjunction with other municipal elections across the province.

Background

The 2022 Ottawa municipal election was the 26th municipal election in the city's history. The election saw a number of incumbent councillors and the mayor seeking re-election, while several new candidates also entered the fray.

article:
Vikram Vedha is a 2022 Indian Hindi-language neo-noir action thriller film written and directed by Pushkar–Gayathri, who also directed the 2017 Tamil original of the same name. The film stars Hrithik Roshan and Saif Ali Khan in the lead roles, with Radhika Apte, Rohit Saraf, and Yogita Bihani in supporting roles.

# Plot

The film is set in the city of Lucknow, Uttar Pradesh, and revolves around the cat-and-mouse game between Vikram (Saif Ali Khan), a tough and honest police officer, and Vedha (Hrithik Roshan), a notorious gangster. The story begins with Vikram, who is tasked with eliminating Vedha, but things take a turn when Vedha voluntarily surrenders to the police and tells Vikram a story about his past, which makes Vikram question his own morality.

As the story unfolds, Vikram becomes entangled in a web of confusion, and his perception of right and wrong begins to blur. Vedha's stories, which initially seem like mere fantasies, start to reveal the darker side of Vikram's own life, forcing him to confront his inner demons. The film's narrative is layered with multiple twists and turns, keeping the audience engaged and guessing until the very end.

# Cast

* Hrithik Roshan as Vedha
* Saif Ali Khan as Vikram
* Radhika Apte as Priya
* Rohit Saraf as Shatak
* Yogita Bihani as Chanda

# Production

## Development

The film was first announced in April 2021, with Hrithik Roshan and Saif Ali Khan on board as the lead actors. The film's script was written by Pushkar–Gayathri, who also directed the 2017 Tamil original. The film's story was inspired by the ancient Indian folklore of Vikram and Betaal, where a king named Vikramaditya is tasked with capturing a ghost named Betaal, who tells him stories to make him question his morality.

## Casting

Hrithik Roshan was the first actor to be cast in the film, and he was reportedly paid a hefty sum for his role. Saif Ali Khan was later cast as the lead opposite Roshan. Radhika Apte, Rohit Saraf, and Yogita Bihani were cast in supporting roles.

## Filming

Principal photography for the film began in October 2021 in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates. The film was shot over a period of several months, with the crew facing several challenges due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The film's cinematography was handled by P.S. Vinod, who also worked on the Tamil original.

# Music

The film's soundtrack was composed by Vishal-Shekhar, who also composed the music for the Tamil original. The film's score was composed by Sam C.S., who also worked on the Tamil original. The film's soundtrack features several popular tracks, including "Alcoholia" and "Bande".

# Marketing

The film's marketing campaign was handled by Yash Raj Films, who released several teasers and trailers for the film. The film's trailer was released in August 2022, and it received a positive response from audiences.

# Release

## Theatrical

The film was released theatrically on September 30, 2022, in India and several other countries. The film received a wide release, with several screens dedicated to it in multiplexes and single-screen theaters.

## Home media

The film was later released on home media platforms, including Amazon Prime Video and DVD. The film's digital rights were acquired by Amazon Prime Video for a reported sum of ₹100 crore.

# Reception

## Box office

The film was a moderate box office success, grossing over ₹150 crore worldwide. The film performed well in its opening weekend, but its collections declined in the subsequent weeks.

## Critical response

The film received generally positive reviews from critics, with several praising the performances of the lead actors. Hrithik Roshan's performance as Vedha was particularly praised, with several calling it one of his best performances in recent years. Saif Ali Khan's performance as Vikram was also praised, with several calling it a nuanced and understated performance.

# Accolades

The film received several awards and nominations, including several Filmfare Awards nominations. Hrithik Roshan won the Best Actor award at the 2023 Filmfare Awards for his performance in the film.

# References

# External links

article:
Singapore at the 2021 SEA Games

The 2021 Southeast Asian Games, officially known as the 31st Southeast Asian Games, were held in Hanoi, Vietnam from 12 to 23 May 2022. Singapore sent a contingent of 659 athletes to compete in 35 sports. This article summarizes the performance of Singapore at the 2021 SEA Games.

# Competitors

Singapore's contingent of 659 athletes was the country's largest ever at the SEA Games. The athletes competed in 35 sports, with the largest teams in aquatics, athletics, and football. The Singapore National Olympic Council (SNOC) selected the athletes based on their performance in international competitions and their potential to win medals.

# Medal summary

Singapore won a total of 47 gold, 46 silver, and 73 bronze medals, finishing fifth in the overall medal tally. This was a decline from the 2019 SEA Games, where Singapore won 53 gold, 46 silver, and 68 bronze medals.

## Medal by sport

Singapore won medals in 21 sports, with the most gold medals coming from aquatics (14) and athletics (8). The country also won multiple gold medals in badminton, table tennis, and shooting.

## Medal by date

Singapore's medal haul was spread throughout the 11 days of competition, with the country winning at least one gold medal on eight of the 11 days. The most successful day for Singapore was 15 May, when the country won five gold medals in aquatics, athletics, and shooting.

# Medallists

A total of 143 Singaporean athletes won medals at the 2021 SEA Games. The most successful athlete was swimmer Quah Zheng Wen, who won four gold medals and one silver medal. Other notable medallists included sprinter Shanti Pereira, who won two gold medals and one silver medal, and shooter Adele Tan, who won two gold medals and one bronze medal.

# Results

## Archery

Singapore's archery team won two bronze medals, with one coming in the men's team event and the other in the mixed team event. The country's top archer, Ang Han Teng, finished fifth in the men's individual event.

## Athletics

Singapore's athletics team won eight gold medals, four silver medals, and six bronze medals. The country's top athlete, Shanti Pereira, won two gold medals and one silver medal in the 100m and 200m events. Other notable performances came from sprinter Marc Brian Louis, who won a silver medal in the 100m event, and distance runner Soh Rui Yong, who won a bronze medal in the 5000m event.

## Badminton

Singapore's badminton team won two gold medals, one silver medal, and three bronze medals. The country's top player, Loh Kean Yew, won a gold medal in the men's singles event and a bronze medal in the mixed doubles event.

## Basketball

### 5x5 Basketball

Singapore's 5x5 basketball team finished fifth in the men's tournament, winning two of their five games. The country's top scorer was Wong Wei Long, who averaged 12.6 points per game.

### 3x3 Basketball

Singapore's 3x3 basketball team won a bronze medal in the men's tournament, finishing third in the round-robin stage and winning the bronze medal match against the Philippines.

## Chess

Singapore's chess team won one gold medal, one silver medal, and two bronze medals. The country's top player, Tin Jingyao, won a gold medal in the men's individual rapid event.

## Football

Singapore's football team finished fourth in the men's tournament, losing to Indonesia in the bronze medal match. The country's top scorer was Ikhsan Fandi, who scored three goals in the tournament.

article:
Tu Jhoothi Main Makkaar

Tu Jhoothi Main Makkaar is a 2023 Indian Hindi-language romantic comedy film directed by Luv Ranjan and written by Rahul Mody and Luv Ranjan. The film features Ranbir Kapoor and Shraddha Kapoor in the lead roles, marking their first on-screen collaboration. The movie follows the story of a young couple who resort to unconventional methods to end their relationship.

#Plot

The film revolves around Rohan Arora (played by Ranbir Kapoor), a young and successful event manager in Delhi, and Nisha Malhotra (played by Shraddha Kapoor), a free-spirited and ambitious woman. The two meet through mutual friends and embark on a whirlwind romance, eventually deciding to get married. However, their relationship takes a turn when they realize that they are not compatible, and their differences become increasingly apparent.

As they struggle to navigate their relationship, Rohan and Nisha resort to unconventional methods to convince each other to break up. They employ the services of a professional "breaker-upper" (played by Dimple Kapadia), who uses unorthodox tactics to drive a wedge between the couple. As the story unfolds, Rohan and Nisha engage in a series of comedic misadventures, each trying to outsmart the other in their quest to end the relationship.

Throughout the film, the characters grapple with themes of love, relationships, and identity, raising questions about the nature of compatibility and the challenges of modern relationships. The movie's title, "Tu Jhoothi Main Makkaar," which translates to "You're a liar, I'm a scammer," reflects the cat-and-mouse game played by the protagonists as they try to outmaneuver each other.

#Cast

* Ranbir Kapoor as Rohan Arora
* Shraddha Kapoor as Nisha Malhotra
* Dimple Kapadia as the Breaker-Upper
* Boney Kapoor as Nisha's father
* Anubhav Singh Bassi as Pandit Ji
* Hasleen Kaur as Nisha's friend
* Monica Chaudhary as Rohan's sister

#Production

##Development

The film was announced in December 2020, with Ranbir Kapoor and Shraddha Kapoor confirmed as the lead actors. Luv Ranjan, known for his work on films like "Pyaar Ka Punchnama" and "Sonu Ke Titu Ki Sweety," was brought on board to direct the project. The script was written by Rahul Mody and Luv Ranjan, with the story credited to Luv Ranjan.

##Casting

Ranbir Kapoor and Shraddha Kapoor were the first choices for the lead roles, and they both accepted the project after reading the script. Dimple Kapadia was cast in a pivotal role as the Breaker-Upper, marking her return to comedy after a long hiatus. The rest of the cast, including Boney Kapoor, Anubhav Singh Bassi, and Monica Chaudhary, were added to the project in the following months.

##Filming

Principal photography began in January 2022 and wrapped up in August 2022. The film was shot on location in Delhi, Mumbai, and Agra, with some scenes also filmed in Spain. The shoot was plagued by delays due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but the cast and crew managed to complete the film on schedule.

#Marketing

The film's marketing campaign kicked off in January 2023, with the release of a teaser trailer that generated significant buzz on social media. The full trailer was released in February 2023, giving fans a glimpse into the film's comedic storyline and the chemistry between the lead actors. The marketing team also launched a series of promotional posters and TV spots, highlighting the film's lighthearted and entertaining tone.

#Soundtrack

The film's soundtrack was composed by Pritam, with lyrics by Amitabh Bhattacharya. The album features six tracks, including the hit single "Tere Pyaar Mein," which was released in February 2023. The song became a chart-topper on music streaming platforms, with fans praising the catchy melody and Ranbir Kapoor's vocals.

#Release

##Theatrical

Tu Jhoothi Main Makkaar was released in theaters on March 8, 2023, on the occasion of International Women's Day. The film received a wide release across India, with over 3,000 screens dedicated to the movie. The film also opened in several international markets, including the United States, the United Kingdom, and Australia.

##Home media

The film's digital rights were acquired by Amazon Prime Video, which released the movie on its platform in April 2023. The film was also made available on DVD and Blu-ray, with fans able to purchase physical copies of the movie.

#Reception

##Critical response

Tu Jhoothi Main Makkaar received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising the film's comedic moments and performances, while others found the storyline and characters to be lacking. The film holds a rating of 50% on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 20 reviews, with an average rating of 5.5/10.

#Box office

The film opened to a decent response at the box office, with a first-day collection of ₹12.5 crore (US$1.6 million). The film's collections improved over the weekend, with a total of ₹40.5 crore (US$5.1 million) earned in its opening weekend. The film went on to gross over ₹100 crore (US$13 million) in its first week, becoming a moderate commercial success.

article:
Pottery
================

Pottery is the art or craft of shaping and firing clay to create vessels, decorative items, and other objects. It is one of the oldest human technologies, dating back to around 9000 BC. Pottery has played a significant role in human history, serving not only as a means of creating functional items but also as a form of artistic expression.

Main Types
------------

### Earthenware

Earthenware is a type of pottery that is fired at a relatively low temperature, typically between 1000°C and 1150°C. It is often made from clay that is rich in iron oxide, which gives it a reddish-brown color. Earthenware is commonly used to create functional items such as plates, bowls, and cups. It is also used to create decorative items like vases and figurines.

### Stoneware

Stoneware is a type of pottery that is fired at a higher temperature than earthenware, typically between 1150°C and 1300°C. It is made from clay that is rich in silica, which gives it a hard, non-porous surface. Stoneware is often used to create functional items like cups, bowls, and plates, as well as decorative items like vases and sculptures.

### Porcelain

Porcelain is a type of pottery that is fired at a very high temperature, typically above 1300°C. It is made from a type of clay called kaolin, which is rich in silica and alumina. Porcelain is known for its whiteness, translucency, and strength. It is often used to create decorative items like vases, figurines, and jewelry, as well as functional items like cups and plates.

Archaeology
------------

### Fabric Analysis

Fabric analysis is a technique used by archaeologists to study the composition and structure of pottery. By analyzing the fabric of pottery, archaeologists can determine the type of clay used, the firing temperature, and the techniques used to shape and decorate the pottery. This information can provide valuable insights into the culture and technology of ancient societies.

Clay Bodies and Raw Materials
------------------------------

Clay bodies are the mixture of clay, water, and other materials used to create pottery. The type of clay used can vary depending on the desired properties of the pottery. For example, clay rich in iron oxide is often used to create earthenware, while clay rich in silica is often used to create stoneware.

Raw materials used in pottery include clay, water, silica, alumina, and metal oxides. The quality and availability of these materials can affect the quality and appearance of the pottery.

Production
------------

### Shaping

Shaping is the process of creating the desired form of the pottery. There are several techniques used to shape pottery, including hand-building, throwing on a wheel, and slip-casting. Hand-building involves shaping the clay by hand, while throwing on a wheel involves using a potter's wheel to shape the clay. Slip-casting involves creating a mold of the desired shape and pouring liquid clay into it.

### Drying

Drying is the process of removing excess moisture from the pottery. This is typically done by air-drying the pottery or by using a drying room. The drying process can take several days or weeks, depending on the thickness of the pottery and the ambient temperature and humidity.

### Firing

Firing is the process of heating the pottery to a high temperature to achieve the desired properties. There are several stages to the firing process, including bisque firing, glaze firing, and reduction firing.

#### Temperature

The temperature of the firing process can vary depending on the type of pottery being created. Earthenware is typically fired at a lower temperature than stoneware or porcelain.

#### Atmosphere

The atmosphere of the firing process can also vary. Oxidation firing involves firing the pottery in the presence of oxygen, while reduction firing involves firing the pottery in the absence of oxygen.

#### Methods

There are several methods of firing pottery, including electric firing, gas firing, and wood firing. Electric firing involves using an electric kiln to heat the pottery, while gas firing involves using a gas-fired kiln. Wood firing involves using a wood-fired kiln to heat the pottery.

#### Stages

The firing process typically involves several stages, including bisque firing, glaze firing, and reduction firing. Bisque firing involves firing the pottery to a low temperature to remove excess moisture and create a hard surface. Glaze firing involves firing the pottery to a higher temperature to melt and set the glaze. Reduction firing involves firing the pottery in the absence of oxygen to create a specific type of glaze.

### Decorating

Decorating is the process of adding color, texture, or other designs to the pottery. There are several techniques used to decorate pottery, including painting, glazing, and slip-trailing. Painting involves applying paint to the pottery, while glazing involves applying a layer of glaze to the pottery. Slip-trailing involves applying a liquid clay to the pottery to create intricate designs.

#### Methods

There are several methods of decorating pottery, including hand-painting, stenciling, and printing. Hand-painting involves painting the pottery by hand, while stenciling involves using a stencil to apply paint to the pottery. Printing involves using a printer to apply designs to the pottery.

### Glazing

Glazing is the process of applying a layer of glaze to the pottery. Glaze is a mixture of chemicals that is applied to the pottery to create a hard, non-porous surface. There are several types of glaze, including clear glaze, colored glaze, and textured glaze.

### Health and Environmental Issues

The production of pottery can involve several health and environmental issues, including the use of toxic materials and the generation of waste. Potters must take precautions to avoid exposure to toxic materials and to minimize waste.

History
--------

### Early Pottery

The earliest pottery dates back to around 9000 BC. Early pottery was made from unglazed clay and was often used for functional purposes such as storing food and water.

### History by Region

The history of pottery varies by region. Here is a brief overview of the history of pottery in different regions:

#### Beginnings of Pottery

The beginnings of pottery date back to around 9000 BC in the Middle East. Early pottery was made from unglazed clay and was often used for functional purposes.

#### East Asia

Pottery has a long history in East Asia, dating back to the Neolithic period. Chinese pottery is famous for its beauty and craftsmanship, with techniques such as glazing and firing developed to a high degree.

#### South Asia

Pottery has a rich history in South Asia, dating back to the Indus Valley Civilization. Indian pottery is known for its intricate designs and patterns, often created using techniques such as slip-trailing.

#### Southeast Asia

Pottery has a significant history in Southeast Asia, dating back to the Neolithic period. Southeast Asian pottery is known for its colorful designs and patterns, often created using techniques such as glazing.

#### West Asia

Pottery has a long history in West Asia, dating back to the Neolithic period. West Asian pottery is known for its intricate designs and patterns, often created using techniques such as slip-trailing.

#### Europe

Pottery has a significant history in Europe, dating back to the Neolithic period. European pottery is known for its beauty and craftsmanship, with techniques such as glazing and firing developed to a high degree.

#### United Kingdom

Pottery has a rich history in the United Kingdom, dating back to the Neolithic period. British pottery is known for its beauty and craftsmanship, with techniques such as glazing and firing developed to a high degree.

#### Arabic Pottery

Arabic pottery has a significant history, dating back to the Islamic Golden Age. Arabic pottery is known for its intricate designs and patterns, often created using techniques such as glazing.

#### Americas

Pottery has a significant history in the Americas, dating back to the pre-Columbian period. American pottery is known for its colorful designs and patterns, often created using techniques such as glazing.

#### Africa

Pottery has a rich history in Africa, dating back to the Neolithic period. African pottery is known for its beauty and craftsmanship, with techniques such as glazing and firing developed to a high degree.

#### Oceania

Pottery has a significant history in Oceania, dating back to the Neolithic period. Oceanian pottery is known for its colorful designs and patterns, often created using techniques such as glazing.

article:
Exodus of Kashmiri Hindus

The exodus of Kashmiri Hindus, also known as the Kashmiri Pandit exodus, was the forced migration of Kashmiri Hindus from the Kashmir Valley in the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir. The event occurred in the early 1990s, during the peak of the Kashmir insurgency, and resulted in the displacement of nearly 100,000 Hindus from the region. The exodus was a result of a combination of factors, including violence, intimidation, and coercion by militant groups, as well as a sense of insecurity and fear among the Kashmiri Hindu community.

#Background

The Kashmir Valley has historically been home to a significant population of Kashmiri Hindus, also known as Kashmiri Pandits. The community has a rich cultural and social heritage, with a distinct language, customs, and traditions. However, the region has also been plagued by communal tensions and conflicts, particularly between Hindus and Muslims.

In the late 1980s, the Kashmir Valley began to experience a surge in militant activity, as various groups, including the Jammu Kashmir Liberation Front (JKLF) and the Hizbul Mujahideen, started to advocate for independence from India. The militants, who were largely Muslim, began to target Kashmiri Hindus, who were seen as a symbol of Indian rule and a potential obstacle to the achievement of independence.

#Insurgency activity

As the insurgency gained momentum, the Kashmir Valley became increasingly unstable. Militants began to attack and intimidate Kashmiri Hindus, forcing many to flee their homes and seek refuge in other parts of the state or in neighboring countries.

##Attack and threats

The militants used various tactics to intimidate and coerce Kashmiri Hindus, including attacks on homes and businesses, kidnappings, and assassinations. Many Kashmiri Hindus were forced to pay extortion money to the militants, while others were forced to flee their homes and seek refuge in other parts of the state.

In 1990, the JKLF issued a warning to Kashmiri Hindus, ordering them to leave the Kashmir Valley within 48 hours. The warning was accompanied by a series of attacks on Kashmiri Hindu homes and businesses, which resulted in the deaths of several people.

#Aftermath

The exodus of Kashmiri Hindus from the Kashmir Valley had a profound impact on the region and its people. The displacement of nearly 100,000 Hindus resulted in a significant loss of cultural and social heritage, as well as a decline in the region's economic and educational development.

Many Kashmiri Hindus were forced to live in refugee camps, where they faced significant challenges, including poverty, unemployment, and poor living conditions. The displacement also had a significant impact on the mental health of the community, with many people experiencing trauma, anxiety, and depression.

#Rehabilitation

In recent years, the Indian government has taken steps to rehabilitate the Kashmiri Hindu community. In 2015, the government announced a package of Rs 1,600 crore to rehabilitate Kashmiri Hindu families who had been displaced from the Kashmir Valley.

The package includes a range of initiatives, including the construction of new homes, the provision of employment opportunities, and the establishment of educational institutions. However, many Kashmiri Hindus have expressed skepticism about the government's efforts, citing a lack of implementation and a failure to address the root causes of the displacement.

#In popular culture

The exodus of Kashmiri Hindus has been the subject of several books, films, and other cultural works.

##Books

* "Our Moon Has Blood Clots" by Rahul Pandita: This book is a personal account of the author's experiences during the exodus of Kashmiri Hindus.
* "The Kashmiri Pandits: A Study of Their Cultural and Social Heritage" by Kashi Nath Pandita: This book provides an overview of the cultural and social heritage of the Kashmiri Pandit community.

##Movies

* "Shikara" (2020): This film, directed by Vidhu Vinod Chopra, tells the story of a Kashmiri Hindu couple who are forced to flee their home during the exodus.
* "The Kashmir Files" (2022): This film, directed by Vivek Agnihotri, tells the story of a Kashmiri Hindu family who are forced to flee their home during the exodus.

#See also

* Kashmir conflict
* Kashmiri Pandits
* Jammu and Kashmir
* Insurgency in Jammu and Kashmir

#Notes

Kelly Townsend

Kelly Townsend is an American politician and activist from Arizona. She has been involved in various aspects of politics, including election activism, child welfare system reform, and advocacy for conservative causes. Townsend has served in the Arizona House of Representatives and Arizona Senate, and has run for higher office, including a failed bid for Congress.

#Early life and education

Kelly Townsend was born and raised in Arizona. She grew up in a family that valued public service and community involvement. Townsend's early life and education played a significant role in shaping her future career in politics. However, specific details about her early life and education are not publicly available.

#Political career and electoral history

##Election activism

Townsend's entry into politics began with election activism. She was involved in various efforts to promote voter integrity and ensure the accuracy of election results. Her activism in this area led to her eventual candidacy for public office.

##Opposition Toward Former House Speaker Rusty Bowers

Townsend was a vocal critic of former Arizona House Speaker Rusty Bowers. She opposed his leadership style and policy decisions, which she believed were not in line with the values of conservative Arizonans. Her criticism of Bowers was seen as a key factor in her eventual election to the Arizona House of Representatives.

##History of Child Welfare System Activism and Judiciary Conflict

Townsend has been a long-time advocate for reforming the child welfare system in Arizona. She has worked to bring attention to the plight of families affected by the system and has pushed for policy changes to improve outcomes for children and families. Her activism in this area has led to conflicts with the judiciary, which she believes has not always acted in the best interests of families.

##School-related activism

Townsend has also been involved in activism related to education. She has advocated for policies that promote parental choice and increase transparency in the education system. Her activism in this area has led to criticism from some educators and education advocates, who believe that her policies would undermine the public education system.

##Ballot Drop Box Monitoring and Voter Intimidation Allegations

During the 2020 election, Townsend was involved in efforts to monitor ballot drop boxes in Arizona. Her actions were criticized by some as an attempt to intimidate voters, which she denied. The controversy surrounding her actions led to increased scrutiny of her campaign and policies.

##COVID-19 Mask Protest

Townsend was a vocal critic of COVID-19 mask mandates and other public health measures implemented during the pandemic. She participated in protests against the mandates and advocated for policies that would allow individuals to make their own decisions about mask-wearing.

##Citizen Alleged Retaliation for Social Media Criticism

Townsend was accused of retaliating against a citizen who criticized her on social media. The citizen alleged that Townsend had used her official position to target them and silence their criticism. The controversy surrounding the allegations led to increased scrutiny of Townsend's actions as a public official.

##ALEC and Article V Convention Activism

Townsend has been involved with the American Legislative Exchange Council (ALEC) and has advocated for an Article V convention to amend the US Constitution. Her activism in this area has been seen as part of a broader effort to promote conservative policies and limit the power of the federal government.

##Arizona House of Representatives

Townsend was first elected to the Arizona House of Representatives in 2012. During her time in the House, she served on several committees, including the House Health Committee and the House Education Committee.

##Arizona Senate
