Cyclone Mocha

Cyclone Mocha was a powerful tropical cyclone that made landfall in Myanmar in May 2023. The cyclone caused widespread destruction and loss of life in several countries in Southeast Asia, including Myanmar, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, India, and China.

# Meteorological history

Cyclone Mocha formed over the Bay of Bengal on May 9, 2023, as a low-pressure system. The system gradually intensified into a cyclonic storm and was named Mocha by the India Meteorological Department (IMD). The cyclone continued to strengthen, reaching super cyclonic storm intensity on May 12.

Mocha's movement was influenced by a subtropical ridge to its north, which caused the cyclone to move northwestwards towards the coast of Myanmar. The cyclone's maximum sustained wind speed reached 240 km/h (150 mph), with gusts of up to 280 km/h (175 mph). The cyclone's central pressure dropped to 930 hPa (27.46 inHg), making it one of the most intense cyclones to affect the region in recent years.

# Effects

The effects of Cyclone Mocha were severe and widespread, affecting several countries in Southeast Asia.

## Myanmar

### Preparations

The Myanmar government issued warnings and evacuation orders for people living in coastal areas, particularly in the Ayeyarwady and Yangon regions. The authorities set up shelters and relief camps for those affected by the cyclone.

### Impact

Cyclone Mocha made landfall in Myanmar on May 14, 2023, causing widespread destruction and loss of life. The cyclone's strong winds and heavy rainfall caused widespread power outages, damaged buildings, and uprooted trees. The worst-affected areas were in the Ayeyarwady and Yangon regions, where thousands of homes were destroyed or damaged.

According to official reports, at least 100 people were killed, and over 1,000 were injured in the cyclone. The cyclone also affected agriculture, with thousands of acres of crops destroyed or damaged.

## Bangladesh

Cyclone Mocha brought heavy rainfall and strong winds to southern Bangladesh, particularly in the Chittagong and Cox's Bazar districts. The cyclone caused widespread flooding and landslides, affecting thousands of people.

According to reports, at least 20 people were killed, and over 100 were injured in Bangladesh. The cyclone also damaged thousands of homes and buildings, particularly in the Chittagong Hill Tracts.

## Sri Lanka

Cyclone Mocha brought strong winds and heavy rainfall to Sri Lanka, particularly in the eastern and southern parts of the country. The cyclone caused widespread power outages and damaged buildings, particularly in the coastal areas.

According to reports, at least 10 people were killed, and over 50 were injured in Sri Lanka. The cyclone also affected agriculture, with thousands of acres of crops destroyed or damaged.

## India

Cyclone Mocha brought heavy rainfall and strong winds to the eastern coast of India, particularly in the states of Odisha and West Bengal. The cyclone caused widespread flooding and landslides, affecting thousands of people.

According to reports, at least 10 people were killed, and over 50 were injured in India. The cyclone also damaged thousands of homes and buildings, particularly in the coastal areas.

## China

Cyclone Mocha brought strong winds and heavy rainfall to southern China, particularly in the provinces of Yunnan and Guangxi. The cyclone caused widespread power outages and damaged buildings, particularly in the mountainous areas.

According to reports, at least 5 people were killed, and over 20 were injured in China. The cyclone also affected agriculture, with thousands of acres of crops destroyed or damaged.

# Aftermath

The aftermath of Cyclone Mocha was marked by widespread relief efforts in the affected countries.

## Myanmar

The Myanmar government deployed troops and relief workers to the affected areas to assist in the rescue and relief efforts. The government also provided food, shelter, and medical aid to those affected by the cyclone.

International organizations, including the United Nations and the Red Cross, provided assistance to the affected countries, including Myanmar. The international community also provided financial aid to support the relief efforts.

In conclusion, Cyclone Mocha was a devastating tropical cyclone that affected several countries in Southeast Asia, causing widespread destruction and loss of life. The cyclone highlighted the need for improved disaster preparedness and response measures in the region.

Depp v. Heard

Depp v. Heard was a highly publicized defamation trial in the United States, in which actor Johnny Depp sued his ex-wife Amber Heard for an op-ed she wrote for The Washington Post in 2018. The trial was widely covered in the media and sparked a global conversation about domestic violence, mental health, and the #MeToo movement.

# Background

## Depp and Heard's relationship

Johnny Depp and Amber Heard began dating in 2012 and got married in 2015. However, their relationship was short-lived, and they filed for divorce in 2016. The divorce was finalized in 2017, with both parties agreeing to a settlement. Despite their divorce, the two continued to make headlines due to their highly publicized and tumultuous relationship.

## Depp v News Group Newspapers Ltd

In 2018, Johnny Depp sued News Group Newspapers Ltd, the publisher of The Sun, for an article that accused him of being a "wife beater." Depp denied the allegations and claimed that the article was defamatory. The case was heard in the UK High Court, and in 2020, the judge ruled in favor of The Sun, stating that the article was "substantially true."

## Heard's op-ed in The Washington Post

In December 2018, Amber Heard wrote an op-ed for The Washington Post, in which she described herself as a survivor of domestic abuse. While she did not mention Johnny Depp by name, many people interpreted the article as a reference to their relationship. Depp's lawyers claimed that the article was defamatory and that it had damaged his reputation.

## Waldman's comments in the Daily Mail

In April 2020, Adam Waldman, Johnny Depp's lawyer, made comments in the Daily Mail, in which he accused Amber Heard of orchestrating a "hoax" against Depp. Waldman claimed that Heard had fabricated allegations of domestic abuse in order to gain leverage in their divorce proceedings.

# Civil action

## Pre-trial developments

In March 2019, Johnny Depp filed a $50 million defamation lawsuit against Amber Heard, claiming that her op-ed in The Washington Post had damaged his reputation. Heard counter-sued Depp for $100 million, alleging that his lawyer, Adam Waldman, had defamed her in the Daily Mail.

## Trial

The trial began on April 11, 2022, and lasted for six weeks. The case was heard in the Fairfax County Circuit Court in Virginia, and Judge Penney Azcarate presided over the trial.

### Opening statements

In their opening statements, Depp's lawyers claimed that Amber Heard had fabricated allegations of domestic abuse in order to gain leverage in their divorce proceedings. Heard's lawyers argued that Depp had a history of violence and that he had abused Heard during their relationship.

### Testimony

During the trial, both Johnny Depp and Amber Heard testified. Depp claimed that he had never hit Heard and that she had been the one to initiate violence in their relationship. Heard testified that Depp had been abusive and that she had feared for her life during their relationship.

### Closing arguments

In their closing arguments, Depp's lawyers claimed that Amber Heard had lied about being a victim of domestic abuse. Heard's lawyers argued that Depp had a history of violence and that he had abused Heard during their relationship.

### Verdict

On June 1, 2022, the jury delivered a verdict in favor of Johnny Depp, finding that Amber Heard had defamed him in her op-ed in The Washington Post. The jury awarded Depp $10.35 million in damages.

## Post-trial motions

After the verdict, Amber Heard's lawyers filed a motion to set aside the verdict, claiming that the jury had been influenced by outside factors. The motion was denied by the judge.

## Appeals, settlement and carrier lawsuit

In July 2022, Amber Heard filed an appeal against the verdict, claiming that the trial had been unfair. In December 2022, Depp and Heard reached a settlement, in which Heard agreed to pay Depp $1 million in damages. In 2023, Depp filed a lawsuit against his insurance carrier, claiming that they had refused to pay his legal fees.

# Reactions

## Livestream

The trial was livestreamed on social media platforms, and millions of people watched the proceedings online. The livestream was widely covered in the media, and many people commented on the trial on social media.

## Social media coverage

The trial was widely covered on social media, with many people commenting on the proceedings using hashtags such as #JusticeForJohnny and #IStandWithAmber. The trial sparked a global conversation about domestic violence, mental health, and the #MeToo movement.

## Comments by juror

After the trial, one of the jurors spoke to the media, saying that the jury had found Amber Heard's testimony to be "inconsistent" and that they had believed Johnny Depp's account of events.

## The Washington Post

The Washington Post, which published Amber Heard's op-ed, issued a statement after the verdict, saying that they stood by their decision to publish the article.

## Commentary on verdict

Many commentators and pundits weighed in on the verdict, with some saying that it was a victory for men's rights and others saying that it was a setback for the #MeToo movement.

# Media coverage

## Film adaptation

In 2022, it was announced that a film adaptation of the trial was in the works, with Johnny Depp set to produce.

## Books

Several books about the trial have been published, including "The Depp-Heard Trial: A Study in Abuse" and "Justice for Johnny: The Inside Story of the Depp-Heard Trial".

## TV

The trial has been the subject of several TV specials and documentaries, including "The Depp-Heard Trial: A Timeline" and "Amber Heard vs. Johnny Depp: The Trial".

## Podcast

A podcast about the trial, "The Depp-Heard Trial Podcast", was launched in 2022, featuring analysis and commentary from experts and pundits.

SpaceX Starship
================

The SpaceX Starship is a reusable spacecraft developed by SpaceX, a private aerospace manufacturer and space transport services company founded by Elon Musk. The Starship is designed to take both people and cargo to the Moon, Mars, and other destinations in the solar system. It is a key component of SpaceX's ambitious plans to establish a permanent human presence on Mars and to make humanity a multi-planetary species.

Description
-----------

The Starship spacecraft is composed of two main parts: the Super Heavy booster and the Starship spacecraft itself.

### Super Heavy booster

The Super Heavy booster is a massive rocket that will provide the necessary thrust to lift the Starship spacecraft off the ground and propel it into space. The booster is powered by a cluster of Raptor engines, which are also used in the Starship spacecraft.

#### Tanks

The Super Heavy booster has a large tank that holds the liquid methane fuel and liquid oxygen oxidizer needed to power the Raptor engines. The tank is made of stainless steel and is designed to be reusable.

#### Propulsion

The Super Heavy booster is powered by a cluster of Raptor engines, which are full-flow staged combustion cycle engines that use liquid methane fuel and liquid oxygen oxidizer. The Raptor engines are capable of producing up to 170 metric tons of thrust each.

#### Interstage

The interstage is the section of the Super Heavy booster that connects the booster to the Starship spacecraft. The interstage is designed to separate from the booster after the booster has completed its job and the Starship spacecraft has reached orbit.

### Starship spacecraft

The Starship spacecraft is the part of the Starship system that carries crew and cargo to their destinations. The spacecraft is designed to be reusable and can carry up to 100 passengers and cargo.

#### Heat shield

The Starship spacecraft has a heat shield that protects it from the intense heat generated during re-entry into the Earth's atmosphere. The heat shield is made of a ceramic material that can withstand temperatures of up to 1,500 degrees Celsius.

#### Variants

There are several variants of the Starship spacecraft, including a crewed version, a cargo version, and a tanker version. The crewed version is designed to carry astronauts to the Moon and Mars, while the cargo version is designed to carry goods and supplies to destinations in space. The tanker version is designed to carry fuel to destinations in space, where it can be used to refuel other spacecraft.

### Raptor engine

The Raptor engine is a full-flow staged combustion cycle engine that uses liquid methane fuel and liquid oxygen oxidizer. The engine is capable of producing up to 170 metric tons of thrust and is used in both the Super Heavy booster and the Starship spacecraft.

The development of the Starship spacecraft has been a long and complex process.

article:
Moonfall (film)

Moonfall is a 2022 science fiction disaster film directed by Roland Emmerich and written by Emmerich, Harald Kloser, and Spenser Cohen. The film stars Patrick Wilson, Halle Berry, John Bradley, Michael Peña, Charlie Plummer, Kelly Yu, and Donald Sutherland. It follows a group of astronauts who must stop the Moon from crashing into Earth after it is knocked out of orbit.

Plot

The film begins with astronaut Brian Harper (Patrick Wilson) on a mission to the Moon with his partner, Marcus. However, their mission is cut short when they encounter a strange anomaly that causes Marcus to disappear. Ten years later, Brian is now a recluse who has lost his reputation and his family due to his erratic behavior. He is visited by a conspiracy theorist named K.C. Houseman (John Bradley), who claims that the Moon is not what it seems.

K.C. reveals that he has discovered that the Moon is not a natural satellite, but a megastructure built by an advanced civilization to monitor and control the Earth. The Moon is also on a collision course with Earth, and K.C. believes that Brian is the only one who can help him stop it. Brian is skeptical, but he is soon convinced when he sees the Moon's orbit begin to decay.

The two men recruit astronaut Jo Fowler (Halle Berry) and her son, Sonny (Charlie Plummer), to help them on their mission. They also enlist the help of General Doug Davidson (Michael Peña) and his team of astronauts. As they journey to the Moon, they encounter numerous obstacles, including treacherous asteroid fields and malfunctioning equipment.

Once they arrive at the Moon, they discover that it is indeed a megastructure, and that it is being controlled by a computer system known as "The Megastructure." The team soon realizes that the only way to stop the Moon from crashing into Earth is to destroy The Megastructure, but this will also destroy the Moon and potentially harm the Earth.

As the team fights to stop the Moon, they also uncover the truth about the Moon's origins and the reason why it was built. They also encounter numerous challenges, including treacherous terrain and malfunctioning equipment. In the end, they are able to destroy The Megastructure and save the Earth, but not without sacrifices.

Moonfall was first announced in 2019, with Roland Emmerich set to direct and Harald Kloser and Spenser Cohen set to write the script. Release

Moonfall was released in the United States on February 4, 2022, by Lionsgate. The film was released in IMAX and Dolby Cinema formats, with a runtime of 130 minutes. The film was rated PG-13 for sequences of violence, action, and destruction, and for language.

Home media

Moonfall was released on digital platforms on April 1, 2022, and on DVD, Blu-ray, and 4K Ultra HD on April 26, 2022. The home media release included a behind-the-scenes featurette, deleted scenes, and a making-of documentary.

Reception

Box office

Moonfall grossed over $60 million worldwide, with $19 million of that coming from the United States. The film's box office performance was considered disappointing, given its estimated budget of $150 million.

Critical response

Moonfall received mixed reviews from critics, with some praising its visuals and action sequences, while others criticized its plot and characters. The film holds a 38% approval rating on Rotten Tomatoes, based on 154 reviews, with an average rating of 4.8/10. article:
Born Pink

Born Pink is the second studio album by South Korean girl group Blackpink, released on September 16, 2022, through YG Entertainment and Interscope Records. The album marks the group's first full-length release in nearly two years, following their debut studio album The Album (2020).

#Background

Blackpink's debut studio album The Album was released in October 2020, and the group had been on hiatus since then, with members focusing on solo activities and collaborations. In March 2022, YG Entertainment announced that Blackpink would be making a comeback with a new album, with the group reportedly working on the album since the beginning of the year. The album's title, Born Pink, was revealed in July 2022, along with the release date and a promotional schedule.

#Recording and development

Recording for Born Pink took place in 2022, with the group working with various producers and songwriters, including Teddy Park, R.Tee, and 24. The album's production was handled by YG Entertainment's in-house producers, with additional work done by international producers. The group's members, Rosé, Jennie, Lisa, and Jisoo, were also involved in the album's creation, with some members contributing to songwriting and composition.

#Music and lyrics

##Composition

Born Pink is a K-pop album that incorporates various genres, including hip hop, EDM, and pop. The album features a mix of upbeat and slow tracks, with the group showcasing their vocal and rapping abilities. The album's production is characterized by heavy beats, synthesizers, and catchy hooks.

##Songs

The album features eight tracks, including the title track "Pink Venom" and the pre-release single "Ready for Love". The album's lead single, "Shut Down", was released on September 16, 2022, along with the album. Other tracks on the album include "Typa Girl", "Yeah Yeah Yeah", "Hard to Love", and "The Happiest Girl".

#Promotion and release

##Marketing

The album's promotional schedule began in July 2022, with the group releasing a series of teasers and concept photos. The group also appeared on various music shows and radio programs, including Music Bank, Show! Music Core, and Inkigayo. The album's release was accompanied by a livestream event on YouTube, where the group performed the album's tracks and interacted with fans.

##Tour

In support of the album, Blackpink embarked on the Born Pink World Tour, which kicked off on October 15, 2022, in Seoul, South Korea. The tour is expected to visit various cities in Asia, North America, and Europe, with additional dates to be announced.

#Artwork and packaging

The album's physical edition features a pink-colored cover with the group's name and album title embossed on it. The album's packaging includes a photobook, a CD, and a random photocard. The album's digital edition features a digital booklet with lyrics and credits.

#Critical reception

Born Pink received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising the group's vocals, rapping, and production. The album was noted for its experimentation with different genres and styles, with some critics praising the group's boldness and creativity.

##Year-end lists

Born Pink was included on various year-end lists, including Billboard's 50 Best Albums of 2022 and Rolling Stone's 50 Best Albums of 2022.

#Awards and nominations

Born Pink has received several awards and nominations, including the Mnet Asian Music Award for Album of the Year and the Melon Music Award for Netizen Popularity Award.

#Commercial performance

Born Pink was a commercial success, debuting at number one on the Gaon Album Chart and the Billboard 200 chart. The album also reached number one on the iTunes Album Chart in various countries, including the United States, Japan, and the United Kingdom.

article:
Convent of Jesus and Mary, Shimla

The Convent of Jesus and Mary, Shimla is a Catholic school for girls in Shimla, Himachal Pradesh, India. Founded in 1864, the school has a rich history spanning over 150 years. It is one of the oldest schools in Shimla and has been a pioneering institution in women's education in the region.

# School foundress (1818 - 1837)

The Convent of Jesus and Mary was founded by Claudine Thévenet, a French Catholic nun, in 1818 in Lyon, France. Claudine Thévenet was born in 1774 and was educated by the Visitation nuns. She was drawn to the apostolate of education and founded the Congregation of Jesus and Mary in 1818. The congregation's primary objective was to provide education to girls and women, particularly those from underprivileged backgrounds. Claudine Thévenet's vision was to empower women through education, and her congregation grew rapidly, establishing schools and convents across Europe and beyond.

# Early history: An orphanage center (1864 - 1940)

In 1864, the Convent of Jesus and Mary established an orphanage center in Shimla, which was then a British hill station. The orphanage was founded by Mother Marie des Anges, a member of the Congregation of Jesus and Mary, who had arrived in India in 1862. The orphanage provided shelter, food, and education to girls from underprivileged backgrounds, many of whom were orphans or had been abandoned by their families. The orphanage was initially housed in a small building in the heart of Shimla and was staffed by a small group of nuns.

## Chelsea chapel 1873

In 1873, the Convent of Jesus and Mary built the Chelsea chapel, a beautiful Gothic-style chapel that still stands today. The chapel was designed by a British architect and was built using local stone and wood. The chapel was consecrated in 1873 and has since been a place of worship and prayer for the nuns, girls, and staff of the convent.

# Boarding school history (1940 - 2000)

In 1940, the Convent of Jesus and Mary began to function as a boarding school, providing education and boarding facilities to girls from across India. The school grew rapidly, and by the 1950s, it had become one of the premier boarding schools in Shimla.

## Boarders

The boarding school was initially housed in the same building as the orphanage, but as the school grew, new buildings were added to accommodate the increasing number of boarders. The boarders were divided into different age groups and were housed in dormitories, each of which was looked after by a matron.

## The Houses

The school was divided into four houses, each named after a saint: St. Claire, St. Joseph, St. Mary, and St. Teresa. The houses were responsible for organizing various events and activities throughout the year, including sports, debates, and cultural programs.

## Dormitories

The dormitories were spacious and well-ventilated, with beds, lockers, and study tables for each girl. The dormitories were looked after by matrons who ensured that the girls kept their belongings tidy and followed the school rules.

## Refectory

The refectory was a large dining hall where the girls had their meals. The refectory was run by a team of cooks and helpers who prepared nutritious meals for the girls.

## Library

The school had a well-stocked library with a wide range of books, including fiction, non-fiction, and reference books. The library was open during school hours, and girls could borrow books to read during their free time.

## Infirmary

The school had a well-equipped infirmary with a trained nurse who looked after the health and well-being of the girls. The infirmary was equipped with basic medical facilities, including beds, first aid kits, and medical equipment.

## Tuck shop

The school had a tuck shop where girls could buy snacks, stationery, and other essentials during school hours. The tuck shop was run by a team of staff members who ensured that the girls got the items they needed.

## Fete

The school organized an annual fete, which was a grand event that brought together girls, parents, and staff. The fete included games, stalls, food, and entertainment, and was a major fundraiser for the school.

## Curriculum

The school followed the ICSE curriculum, which included subjects such as English, Hindi, mathematics, science, social studies, and languages. The school also offered a range of extracurricular activities, including sports, music, and dance.

## School outings

The school organized regular outings and excursions for the girls, including trips to local landmarks, museums, and other places of interest. The outings were designed to broaden the girls' knowledge and understanding of the world around them.

## Miss Chelsea (Graduation Farewell)

The school organized an annual graduation farewell ceremony, which was called Miss Chelsea. The ceremony included a fashion show, music, and dance, and was a celebration of the girls' achievements and talents.

# The teachers cottage

The teachers' cottage was a separate building that housed the school's staff members. The cottage was equipped with basic amenities, including beds, kitchens, and bathrooms, and was a comfortable and convenient place for the staff to live and work.

# Day school history (2001 to present)

In 2001, the Convent of Jesus and Mary began to function as a day school, providing education to girls from Shimla and surrounding areas. The school continued to follow the ICSE curriculum and offered a range of extracurricular activities.

## School achievements

The school has achieved excellent results in the ICSE exams, with many girls scoring high grades and going on to pursue higher education. The school has also won several awards and accolades for its academic and extracurricular achievements.

## School participation at state level and inter-school competitions

The school participates in various state-level and inter-school competitions, including sports, debates, and cultural programs. The school has won several awards and accolades for its achievements in these areas.

# Lifetime of service

The Convent of Jesus and Mary has a long history of service to the community, and has been a pioneering institution in women's education in Shimla. The school continues to provide education and empowerment to girls from underprivileged backgrounds, and is committed to its mission of promoting education and social justice.

Ayman al-Zawahiri is an Egyptian physician, theologian, and militant Islamist who served as the General Emir of al-Qaeda from 2011 until his death in 2022. He was a key figure in the global jihadist movement and a longtime associate of Osama bin Laden.

# Personal life

article:
Big Brother Canada Season 10

Big Brother Canada Season 10 is the tenth season of the Canadian reality television series Big Brother Canada. The season premiered on March 2, 2022, and concluded on May 5, 2022. The show was broadcast on Global and streamed on the Global TV app.

#Production

##Development

The tenth season of Big Brother Canada was announced on November 3, 2021, with Arisa Cox returning as the host. The season was produced by Insight Productions and Endemol Shine North America, with John Brunton, Erin Brock, and Eric Abboud serving as executive producers.

##Prizes

The grand prize for the season was $100,000 and the title of Big Brother Canada winner. The runner-up received $20,000. Additionally, the winner of the season also received a $25,000 bonus for being the winner of the season.

##Production design

The Big Brother Canada house was located in Toronto, Ontario, and was designed by Peter Faragher. The house had a total of 87 cameras and 142 microphones to capture the actions of the houseguests. The house was also equipped with a backyard, a pool, and a hot tub.

##International broadcast

The season was broadcast on Global in Canada and was also available to stream on the Global TV app. The season was also broadcast on Slice in Canada. Internationally, the season was broadcast on CBS in the United States as a simulcast of the Canadian broadcast.

#HouseGuests

##Guests

The season featured 16 houseguests, including 8 men and 8 women. The houseguests were from different parts of Canada and had different backgrounds and occupations.

The houseguests were:

* Adam Pike, a 29-year-old oil rig worker from St. John's, Newfoundland and Labrador
* Alejandra Martinez, a 24-year-old student from Vancouver, British Columbia
* Anthony Douglas, a 32-year-old police officer from Toronto, Ontario
* Autumn Cooke, a 29-year-old bartender from Calgary, Alberta
* Beth Bieda, a 29-year-old marketing manager from Toronto, Ontario
* Chris Wyllie, a 28-year-old entrepreneur from Vancouver, British Columbia
* Damien Ketlo, a 29-year-old oil rig worker from Fort McMurray, Alberta
* Danny Arroyo, a 33-year-old fashion designer from Toronto, Ontario
* Gino Chouinard, a 31-year-old electrician from Montreal, Quebec
* Hope Agbolosoo, a 23-year-old nurse from Regina, Saskatchewan
* Jess Gowling, a 25-year-old event coordinator from Toronto, Ontario
* John Michael Sosa, a 27-year-old model from Vancouver, British Columbia
* Kevin Jacobs, a 28-year-old teacher from Winnipeg, Manitoba
* Kyle Moore, a 26-year-old personal trainer from Toronto, Ontario
* Martin Bigsby, a 30-year-old lawyer from Calgary, Alberta

#Format

The season followed the same format as previous seasons of Big Brother Canada. The houseguests lived together in the Big Brother Canada house and competed in challenges to win power and prizes. Each week, one houseguest was nominated for eviction by the head of household, and the other houseguests voted on which nominee to evict.

#Twists

##Phone Room

The Phone Room twist returned for the season, where houseguests could earn the power to save themselves or another houseguest from nomination.

##Belairdirect Eviction Protection Insurance

The Belairdirect Eviction Protection Insurance twist allowed houseguests to earn protection from eviction for one week.

##Chain of Safety Double Eviction

The Chain of Safety Double Eviction twist allowed the winner of the power of veto to save one of the nominees and force the head of household to name a replacement nominee.

##Canada's Jury Vote

The Canada's Jury Vote twist allowed the Canadian public to vote for their favorite houseguest to win a cash prize and a spot in the jury.

#Summary

The season was marked by several twists and turns, including the return of the Phone Room and the introduction of the Chain of Safety Double Eviction. The season also saw several strong alliances form, including the "Misfits" alliance, which consisted of houseguests Adam, Alejandra, and Anthony.

The season also saw several surprise evictions, including the eviction of houseguest Autumn, who was seen as a strong physical competitor. The season also saw the rise of houseguest Gino, who became one of the strongest players in the game.

In the end, houseguest Gino was crowned the winner of the season, taking home the grand prize of $100,000 and the title of Big Brother Canada winner.

#Episodes

The season consisted of 29 episodes, including the premiere and finale.

#Have-Nots

The Have-Nots were houseguests who were chosen to eat slop, a type of oatmeal, for a week. The Have-Nots for the season were:

* Week 1: Adam, Alejandra, and Anthony
* Week 2: Autumn, Beth, and Chris
* Week 3: Damien, Danny, and Gino
* Week 4: Hope, Jess, and John
* Week 5: Kevin, Kyle, and Martin

#Voting history

The voting history for the season was as follows:

* Week 1: Autumn was nominated by the head of household, but was saved by the power of veto. Chris was nominated as the replacement nominee and was evicted by a vote of 10-2.
* Week 2: Damien was nominated by the head of household and was evicted by a vote of 9-3.
* Week 3: Beth was nominated by the head of household, but was saved by the power of veto. Danny was nominated as the replacement nominee and was evicted by a vote of 8-4.
* Week 4: Autumn was nominated by the head of household and was evicted by a vote of 7-5.
* Week 5: John was nominated by the head of household, but was saved by the power of veto. Hope was nominated as the replacement nominee and was evicted by a vote of 6-6, with the tiebreaker vote cast by the head of household.
* Week 6: Kevin was nominated by the head of household and was evicted by a vote of 5-5, with the tiebreaker vote cast by the head of household.
* Week 7: Martin was nominated by the head of household, but was saved by the power of veto. Kyle was nominated as the replacement nominee and was evicted by a vote of 4-4, with the tiebreaker vote cast by the head of household.
* Week 8: Jess was nominated by the head of household and was evicted by a vote of 3-3, with the tiebreaker vote cast by the head of household.
* Week 9: Anthony was nominated by the head of household and was evicted by a vote of 2-2, with the tiebreaker vote cast by the head of household.

article:
Kanjuruhan Stadium disaster

The Kanjuruhan Stadium disaster was a tragic event that occurred on October 1, 2022, at the Kanjuruhan Stadium in Malang, East Java, Indonesia. The disaster happened during a football match between Arema FC and Persebaya Surabaya, resulting in one of the deadliest stadium disasters in history.

#Background

The Kanjuruhan Stadium, located in Malang, East Java, Indonesia, has a seating capacity of approximately 42,000 spectators. On the day of the match, the stadium was filled with fans of both Arema FC and Persebaya Surabaya, with a reported attendance of around 42,000 spectators. The match was a highly anticipated event, with Arema FC seeking to secure a vital win in the Indonesian Liga 1.

#Disaster

On October 1, 2022, at around 9:30 PM local time, a violent clash broke out between fans of Arema FC and Persebaya Surabaya. The disturbance began when Arema FC fans invaded the pitch, resulting in a stampede that pushed fans against the stadium's doors and walls. The police responded by firing tear gas into the crowd, which further exacerbated the situation. The gas caused widespread panic, leading to a massive stampede that crushed many fans.

#Casualties

The disaster resulted in a significant loss of life, with 135 people confirmed dead and over 500 injured. Many of the victims were trampled or suffocated in the stampede.

##Ages and genders

The victims of the disaster included both men and women, with the majority being young adults. The ages of the victims ranged from 2 to 55 years old, with the majority being between 15 and 30 years old.

#Aftermath

The disaster sparked widespread shock and outrage across Indonesia and the world. The government immediately launched an investigation into the incident, and the police chief of East Java was dismissed in response to the tragedy. The Kanjuruhan Stadium was also closed temporarily pending the outcome of the investigation.

#Legal

The disaster raised questions about the accountability of the stadium's management, the police, and the Indonesian Football Association (PSSI). The government announced plans to review the country's stadium safety regulations and to take action against those responsible for the tragedy.

#Investigation

##Police

The police launched an investigation into the disaster, focusing on the actions of the stadium's management, the police, and the fans. The investigation found that the police had fired tear gas into the crowd without proper justification, which contributed to the stampede.

##Joint fact-finding team

A joint fact-finding team was established by the government to investigate the disaster. The team, comprising representatives from the government, the police, and the PSSI, found that a combination of factors contributed to the tragedy, including inadequate stadium safety measures, poor crowd control, and the use of tear gas.

##Autopsie

The event took place from June 20 to June 25, 2023, in Silesia, Poland, as part of the 2023 European Games.

# Format change

The 2023 European Athletics Team Championships saw a significant change in format. Unlike previous editions, where the competition was divided into four leagues, the 2023 edition featured three divisions. article:
2022 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament

The 2022 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament was the 84th edition of the single-elimination tournament held to determine the champion of the National Collegiate Athletic Association (NCAA) Division I men's basketball. The tournament began on March 14, 2022, and concluded on April 4, 2022.

#Tournament procedure

The tournament procedure consists of several rounds, with each round featuring a single-elimination format. The tournament starts with the First Four games, followed by the Round of 64, the Round of 32, the Sweet 16, the Elite Eight, the Final Four, and finally, the National Championship game. The teams that lose in each round are eliminated from the tournament, while the winners advance to the next round.

#2022 NCAA Tournament schedule and venues

The 2022 NCAA Tournament schedule and venues were announced on March 13, 2022. The tournament was held at 14 different venues across the United States, with the Final Four games taking place at the Caesars Superdome in New Orleans, Louisiana.

* First Four: University of Dayton Arena (Dayton, OH) – March 14-15, 2022
* East Regional: Wells Fargo Center (Philadelphia, PA) – March 24-26, 2022
* South Regional: AT&T Center (San Antonio, TX) – March 24-26, 2022
* Midwest Regional: United Center (Chicago, IL) – March 25-27, 2022
* West Regional: Chase Center (San Francisco, CA) – March 24-26, 2022
* Final Four: Caesars Superdome (New Orleans, LA) – April 2-4, 2022

#Qualification and selection of teams

A total of 68 teams qualified for the 2022 NCAA Tournament. The teams were selected and seeded by the NCAA Selection Committee.

##Automatic qualifiers

* 32 conference champions received automatic bids to the tournament.

##Tournament seeds

* The remaining 36 teams were selected at-large and seeded by the NCAA Selection Committee.
* The teams were seeded 1-16 in each region, with the top four teams in each region receiving a top-four seed.

#Tournament bracket

article:
Timeline of the COVID-19 pandemic in February 2022

The COVID-19 pandemic, which began in late 2019, continued to spread globally throughout February 2022. This article provides a comprehensive timeline of major events and responses to the pandemic during this month.

# Case statistics

As of February 28, 2022, the global number of reported COVID-19 cases had surpassed 425 million, with over 6 million reported deaths. The Omicron variant, which had been detected in many countries since its emergence in late 2021, remained the dominant strain of the virus.

# Pandemic chronology

## 1 February

On February 1, the World Health Organization (WHO) reported that the global number of new COVID-19 cases had decreased by 20% compared to the previous week. The WHO also noted that the number of hospitalizations and deaths had also decreased.

## 2 February

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) in the United States announced that it would be expanding its COVID-19 vaccine booster shot program to include children aged 12-15 years. The CDC also recommended that all adults aged 18-49 years with certain underlying health conditions receive a booster shot.

## 3 February

The European Union (EU) announced that it would be lifting its travel ban on non-essential travel from the United States, effective immediately. The EU had imposed the ban in March 2020 in response to the spread of COVID-19.

## 4 February

The WHO announced that it would be sending a team of experts to China to investigate the origins of the COVID-19 pandemic. The team would be led by Dr. Peter Ben Embarek, a Danish scientist who had previously led a WHO mission to China in 2021.

## 5 February

The government of Japan announced that it would be extending its state of emergency in response to the COVID-19 pandemic until March 21. The state of emergency had been in place since January 21.

## 6 February

The CDC announced that it would be launching a new COVID-19 vaccine program aimed at protecting people with weakened immune systems. The program would provide an additional dose of the vaccine to people with conditions such as cancer and HIV.

## 7 February

The WHO announced that it would be providing COVID-19 vaccines to the Palestinian territories. The vaccines would be provided through the WHO's COVAX program, which aims to provide vaccines to low- and middle-income countries.

## 8 February

The government of Australia announced that it would be reopening its borders to international travelers, effective February 21. The borders had been closed since March 2020 in response to the spread of COVID-19.

## 9 February

The CDC announced that it would be updating its COVID-19 vaccine guidance to include a recommendation that all adults aged 50 years and older receive a booster shot. The CDC also recommended that all adults with certain underlying health conditions receive a booster shot.

## 10 February

The WHO announced that it would be launching a new program aimed at providing COVID-19 vaccines to refugees and migrants. The program would be implemented in partnership with the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR).

## 11 February

The government of Canada announced that it would be lifting its travel ban on non-essential travel from the United States, effective February 15. The ban had been in place since March 2020 in response to the spread of COVID-19.

## 12 February

The CDC announced that it would be expanding its COVID-19 vaccine program to include children aged 5-11 years with certain underlying health conditions. The CDC also recommended that all adults with certain underlying health conditions receive a booster shot.

## 13 February

The WHO announced that it would be providing COVID-19 vaccines to the Democratic Republic of Congo. The vaccines would be provided through the WHO's COVAX program.

## 14 February

article:
2022 Texas House of Representatives Election

The 2022 Texas House of Representatives election was held on November 8, 2022, to elect all 150 members of the Texas House of Representatives. This election coincided with the elections for other state and federal offices.

#Background

The Texas House of Representatives is the lower house of the Texas Legislature. It is composed of 150 members, each representing a district in the state. The members serve two-year terms and are elected in even-numbered years. The 2022 election was the first to be held under new district boundaries, which were redrawn following the 2020 United States Census.

#Redistricting

##Seats without incumbents

Due to the redistricting process, some districts were created or reconfigured to have no incumbent representative seeking re-election. These districts were:

* District 37: A new district created in the Rio Grande Valley.
* District 38: A new district created in the Houston area.
* District 70: A reconfigured district in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

##Double-bunked incumbents

In some cases, the redistricting process resulted in two incumbent representatives being drawn into the same district. These districts were:

* District 19: Incumbents Terry Wilson and Ellen Troxclair were both drawn into this district.
* District 24: Incumbents Greg Bonnen and Mayes Middleton were both drawn into this district.

#Retirements

Several incumbent representatives announced their retirement prior to the election. These included:

* District 4: Lance Gooden announced his retirement to run for the U.S. House of Representatives.
* District 17: John Cyrier announced his retirement to run for the Texas Senate.
* District 60: Mike Lang announced his retirement to run for the Texas Senate.

#Special elections

There were no special elections held in 2022 to fill vacant seats in the Texas House of Representatives.

#Incumbents defeated

##In primaries

###Democrats

* District 27: Incumbent Ron Reynolds lost the primary to challenger Steve Brown.
* District 46: Incumbent Sheryl Cole lost the primary to challenger Jose Velasquez.

###Republicans

* District 12: Incumbent Kyle Kacal lost the primary to challenger Ben Bius.
* District 64: Incumbent Lynn Stucky lost the primary to challenger David Spiller.

#Predictions

##Statewide

Most predictions indicated that the Republican Party would maintain its majority in the Texas House of Representatives.

##Competitive districts

Several districts were identified as competitive, including:

* District 21: A swing district in the Houston area.
* District 28: A swing district in the Houston area.
* District 65: A swing district in the Dallas-Fort Worth area.

#Summary of results

##Statewide

The Republican Party maintained its majority in the Texas House of Representatives, winning 86 seats to the Democratic Party's 64 seats.

##Close races

Several districts had close results, including:

* District 21: The Republican candidate won by a margin of 1.2%.
* District 28: The Republican candidate won by a margin of 2.1%.
* District 65: The Democratic candidate won by a margin of 1.5%.

article:
AEL Limassol B.C.
================

AEL Limassol B.C. is a Cypriot professional basketball club based in Limassol, Cyprus. The team has a rich history, having been founded in 1966 and having experienced various periods of success and decline over the years.

History
-------

### Founding, early years & First Golden Age (1966–1988)

AEL Limassol B.C. was founded in 1966, and the team quickly established itself as a dominant force in Cypriot basketball. During the 1970s and 1980s, AEL won numerous domestic titles, including several championships and cups. The team's success during this period was largely due to the presence of talented players such as Andreas Paschalidis and Giorgos Stylianou.

### Decline, relegation & return to glory (1989–2001)

In the late 1980s, AEL experienced a decline in fortunes, which resulted in the team being relegated to the second division. However, the team bounced back in the early 1990s, winning promotion back to the top division and eventually claiming several more domestic titles. During this period, AEL also began to participate in European competitions, competing in the FIBA European Cup and the FIBA Korać Cup.

### Second Golden Age & various European successes (2002–2010)

#### The initial Dragan Raca era (2002–2005)

In 2002, AEL appointed Dragan Raca as head coach, marking the beginning of a new era of success for the team. Under Raca's guidance, AEL won several domestic titles and enjoyed success in European competitions, including a quarterfinal appearance in the FIBA EuroCup.

#### Organising the FIBA EuroCup All-Star Day Limassol & interest to join Greek A1 Basketball League (2006–2008)

In 2006, AEL hosted the FIBA EuroCup All-Star Day, a prestigious event that brought together some of the top players in European basketball. The team also expressed interest in joining the Greek A1 Basketball League, one of the top leagues in Europe. Although the move ultimately did not materialize, it reflected the team's ambition and desire to compete at the highest level.

#### Transformation from EuroChallenge contenders to EuroChallenge favourites (2008–2010)

In 2008, AEL began to participate in the FIBA EuroChallenge, a competition that pitted the team against some of the top clubs in Europe. Under the guidance of coach Raca, AEL quickly established itself as a contender, reaching the quarterfinals in 2009 and the semifinals in 2010.

### Descent into obscurity, dissolution & reformation (2011–2017)

In 2011, AEL experienced a decline in fortunes, which resulted in the team being relegated to the second division. The team eventually ceased operations, only to be reformed in 2017.

### Recent history (2018–present)

#### Return to Division A & reaching two Cup finals (2018–2022)

In 2018, AEL returned to the top division and quickly established itself as a contender, reaching two cup finals in 2019 and 2020.

#### Gradual improvements & participation in the Balkan League (2023–)

In 2023, AEL began to participate in the Balkan League, a regional competition that pitted the team against some of the top clubs in the region. The team has continued to show gradual improvements, reflecting its commitment to developing young players and competing at the highest level.

2022 European Championships
==========================

The 2022 European Championships was a multi-sport event held in Munich, Germany, from August 11 to August 21, 2022. The event brought together some of the continent's top athletes in nine different sports, competing for medals and national pride. This article provides an overview of the championships, including the venues, calendar, medal table, results and standings, participating teams, and other relevant information.

# Venues
--------

The 2022 European Championships took place in Munich, Germany, with events held at various venues across the city. The main venues included:

* Olympiapark: A large sports complex built for the 1972 Summer Olympics, which hosted events such as athletics, gymnastics, and cycling.
* Olympiahalle: An indoor arena located within the Olympiapark, which hosted events such as basketball and table tennis.
* English Garden: A large public park in the heart of Munich, which hosted events such as rowing and canoeing.
* Nymphenburg Palace Park: A beautiful park located in the north of Munich, which hosted events such as triathlon and cycling.

## Venue Capacity

The venues used for the 2022 European Championships had a combined capacity of over 100,000 spectators, ensuring that fans could watch their favorite athletes in action.

Season 31 of Dancing with the Stars premiered on September 19, 2022, on Disney+. The season featured a new judging panel and a fresh batch of celebrities competing for the coveted Mirrorball Trophy.

article:
Eureka Rebellion

The Eureka Rebellion was a pivotal event in Australian history that took place on December 3, 1854, in Ballarat, Victoria. It was a rebellion of gold miners against the colonial government, which culminated in the Battle of the Eureka Stockade. The rebellion was sparked by a series of grievances, including the imposition of a mining tax, the lack of representation in the government, and the mistreatment of miners by the authorities.

# Origins in the Victorian gold rush

The Victorian gold rush, which began in 1851, brought a massive influx of migrants to the colony, including many from China, Europe, and North America. The goldfields were a hotbed of activity, with thousands of miners seeking to strike it rich. However, the colonial government, led by Governor Charles La Trobe, saw the gold rush as an opportunity to raise revenue and imposed a series of taxes and regulations on the miners.

## Protests on the goldfields: 1851–1854

The miners were unhappy with the government's policies, and protests began to erupt on the goldfields. In 1851, La Trobe introduced a monthly mining tax, which the miners saw as excessive and unfair. The tax was set at 30 shillings per month, which was a significant burden on the miners, many of whom were struggling to make a living.

### La Trobe introduces monthly mining tax as protests begin

The introduction of the mining tax sparked widespread protests on the goldfields. Miners argued that the tax was unfair and that it would drive them out of business. They also complained about the lack of representation in the government and the mistreatment of miners by the authorities.

### First gold commissioner arrives in Ballarat

In 1852, the first gold commissioner, Robert William Rede, arrived in Ballarat. Rede was tasked with implementing the government's policies on the goldfields, but he soon found himself at odds with the miners. The miners saw Rede as a symbol of the government's oppressive policies, and he became a target of their protests.

### Bendigo Petition and the Red Ribbon Movement

In 1853, a group of miners in Bendigo, led by George Thomson, presented a petition to the government calling for the abolition of the mining tax and the introduction of democratic reforms. The petition was signed by thousands of miners and became known as the Bendigo Petition. The petition was accompanied by a red ribbon movement, in which miners wore red ribbons on their hats to show their support for the petition.

### Legislative Council calls for Commission of Inquiry

In response to the growing unrest on the goldfields, the Legislative Council called for a Commission of Inquiry to investigate the grievances of the miners. The commission was established in 1854 and was tasked with investigating the mining tax, the administration of the goldfields, and the treatment of miners by the authorities.

### Hotham replaces La Trobe

In 1854, Governor La Trobe was replaced by Sir Charles Hotham. Hotham was tasked with implementing the recommendations of the Commission of Inquiry, but he soon found himself facing opposition from the miners.

# Tensions escalate

The tensions between the miners and the government continued to escalate in the months leading up to the Eureka Rebellion. In October 1854, a group of miners attacked and burned down the Eureka Hotel, which was owned by James Bentley, a former police officer. Bentley was accused of being a government informer and of mistreating miners.

## Murder of James Scobie and the burning of the Eureka hotel

The burning of the Eureka Hotel was sparked by the murder of James Scobie, a miner who had been involved in a dispute with Bentley. Scobie's death was seen as a symbol of the government's oppression of the miners, and it sparked widespread outrage.

## Ballarat Reform League meetings

In the aftermath of the burning of the Eureka Hotel, a group of miners formed the Ballarat Reform League. The league was led by Peter Lalor, a charismatic leader who would become a key figure in the Eureka Rebellion. The league held a series of meetings, at which they called for democratic reforms and the abolition of the mining tax.

## Escalating violence as military convoy looted

As the tensions between the miners and the government continued to escalate, violence began to break out on the goldfields. In November 1854, a military convoy was looted by a group of miners, and several soldiers were injured. The incident marked a turning point in the conflict, as it showed that the miners were willing to use violence to achieve their goals.

# Open rebellion

The Eureka Rebellion began on November 29, 1854, when a group of miners, led by Peter Lalor, swore allegiance to the Southern Cross flag. The flag was a symbol of the miners' rebellion against the government, and it would become a powerful symbol of Australian nationalism.

## Paramilitary mobilisation and swearing allegiance to the Southern Cross

The miners, who were largely armed and organized, began to mobilize for a confrontation with the government. On November 29, they gathered at Bakery Hill, where they swore allegiance to the Southern Cross flag. The flag was a symbol of the miners' rebellion against the government, and it would become a powerful symbol of Australian nationalism.

### Fortification of the Eureka lead

The miners, led by Lalor, began to fortify the Eureka lead, which was a strategic location on the goldfields. They built a stockade, which was a makeshift fortification made of wood and earth. The stockade was designed to protect the miners from the government's troops, who were expected to arrive at any moment.

#### Vinegar Hill blunder: Irish dimension factors in dwindling numbers at stockade

However, the miners' plans were compromised when a group of Irish miners, who had been involved in the rebellion, were persuaded to leave the stockade by a Catholic priest. The priest, who was sympathetic to the government's cause, told the miners that they would be committing a mortal sin if they continued to rebel against the authorities. The loss of the Irish miners weakened the rebels' position and reduced their numbers.

#### Departing detachment of Independent Californian Rangers leaves small garrison behind

A detachment of the Independent Californian Rangers, who had been sympathetic to the miners' cause, left the stockade and returned to their camp. The departure of the Rangers left a small garrison behind, which was largely made up of inexperienced miners.

## Battle of the Eureka Stockade

The Battle of the Eureka Stockade took place on December 3, 1854, when a group of government troops, led by Captain John Thomas, attacked the stockade. The battle was fierce, but the miners were heavily outnumbered and outgunned. After a brief but intense battle, the stockade was breached, and the miners were defeated.

# Aftermath

The aftermath of the Eureka Rebellion was marked by a series of trials and inquiries. The government, which had been shaken by the rebellion, was determined to punish the miners and to prevent future uprisings.

## Trials for sedition and high treason

Thirteen miners were put on trial for sedition and high treason. The trials were widely publicized, and they sparked widespread outrage. The miners were defended by a team of lawyers, who argued that they had been exercising their right to protest against an unjust government.

## Commission of Inquiry report

The Commission of Inquiry, which had been established to investigate the rebellion, published its report in 1855. The report was critical of the government's handling of the rebellion and recommended a series of reforms, including the abolition of the mining tax and the introduction of democratic reforms.

## Peter Lalor enters parliament

Peter Lalor, who had been a key figure in the Eureka Rebellion, entered parliament in 1856. Lalor became a vocal advocate for democratic reforms and played a key role in shaping the development of Australian democracy.

# Location of Bakery Hill and the Eureka Stockade

The Eureka Stockade was located on the Eureka lead, which was a strategic location on the goldfields. The stockade was situated near Bakery Hill, which was a prominent landmark in the area. Today, the site of the Eureka Stockade is commemorated by a museum and a memorial.

# Political legacy

The Eureka Rebellion had a profound impact on Australian politics. The rebellion marked a turning point in the development of Australian democracy, as it highlighted the need for democratic reforms and the protection of citizens' rights. The rebellion also led to the establishment of the first democratic parliament in Victoria and paved the way for the development of Australian nationalism.

# Commemoration

The Eureka Rebellion has been commemorated in a variety of ways over the years.

## 19th century

In the 19th century, the Eureka Rebellion was commemorated by a series of anniversaries and events. The rebellion was seen as a symbol of Australian nationalism, and it was celebrated by many as a heroic event.

## 20th century

In the 20th century, the Eureka Rebellion was commemorated by a series of events and exhibitions. The rebellion was seen as a key event in Australian history, and it was celebrated by many as a symbol of Australian democracy.

## 21st century

Today, the Eureka Rebellion is commemorated by a museum and a memorial at the site of the stockade. The rebellion is also celebrated by a series of events and anniversaries, including the annual Eureka Day celebrations.

# Popular culture

The Eureka Rebellion has been depicted in a variety of ways in popular culture.

## Literature

The rebellion has been the subject of several books and novels, including Raffaello Carboni's "The Eureka Stockade" and Frank Hardy's "The Unlucky Australians".

## Film and television

The rebellion has been depicted in several films and television programs, including the 1949 film "Eureka Stockade" and the 1981 television series "The Eureka Stockade".

## Music

The rebellion has been celebrated in several songs and ballads, including the famous "Eureka Flag" song.

2023 in Film

The year 2023 in film is expected to be filled with a wide range of exciting releases, from blockbuster franchises to independent dramas. As the film industry continues to evolve, 2023 promises to be a year of innovation, creativity, and entertainment.

The year 2023 in film is shaping up to be a significant one, with many highly anticipated releases scheduled for the upcoming months. The film industry has been impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic, but 2023 is expected to see a resurgence in box office numbers and a renewed focus on cinematic innovation. With the rise of streaming services, the traditional film distribution model is changing, and 2023 will likely see further experimentation with new release strategies and platforms.

article:
Anna Sorokin

Anna Sorokin is a Russian-born German con artist and socialite. She was born on January 23, 1991, in Domodedovo, Russia. Sorokin gained international attention for posing as a wealthy heiress and swindling numerous individuals and businesses out of thousands of dollars. Her crimes were highly publicized, and she was eventually arrested, tried, and convicted of multiple counts of grand larceny.

#Early life

Anna Sorokin was born in Domodedovo, Russia, a suburb of Moscow. Her father, Vladimir Sorokin, was a truck driver, and her mother, Irina Sorokina, was a homemaker. In 2007, the family moved to Germany, where Sorokin's father worked as a transportation executive. She attended a private school in Eschweiler, Germany, where she learned fluent English and developed an interest in fashion and design.

In 2011, Sorokin moved to Paris to study at a fashion school, but she dropped out after one year. She then relocated to New York City, where she began to build a reputation as a socialite and fashion influencer. Sorokin created a fake backstory, claiming to be a wealthy heiress with a trust fund, and began to attend high-end events and parties.

#Fraud

Between 2013 and 2017, Sorokin committed a series of scams and thefts, targeting wealthy individuals, hotels, and businesses. She would often pose as a wealthy heiress, using fake identities and backstories to gain the trust of her victims. Sorokin would then use this trust to borrow money, secure loans, or obtain free goods and services.

Some of Sorokin's notable scams included:

* Convincing a private jet company to fly her and her friends to Nebraska, promising to pay $35,000 for the trip, which she never did.
* Posing as a wealthy client to secure a $100,000 loan from a bank, which she used to fund her lavish lifestyle.
* Staying at luxury hotels, such as the Beekman and the Mercer, without paying, and charging thousands of dollars to other people's credit cards.
* Convincing a fashion designer to create a custom wardrobe for her, worth over $60,000, which she never paid for.

Sorokin's scams were often brazen and reckless, and she was eventually caught after a series of complaints and investigations.

#Indictment and arrest

On November 14, 2016, Sorokin was arrested at the Beekman Hotel, where she had been staying for several weeks without paying. She was charged with multiple counts of grand larceny, theft of services, and attempted grand larceny.

In 2017, Sorokin was indicted on 10 counts of grand larceny, theft of services, and attempted grand larceny. She was released on bail, but failed to appear in court, leading to a warrant being issued for her arrest.

Sorokin was rearrested in October 2017, and held without bail. Her trial began in April 2019, and lasted for several weeks.

#Trial, conviction, and sentence

During her trial, Sorokin's defense team argued that she was a "daddy's girl" who had been led astray by her wealthy upbringing. However, prosecutors presented evidence of Sorokin's elaborate scams and thefts, and several of her victims testified against her.

On May 9, 2019, Sorokin was convicted of eight counts of grand larceny and theft of services. She was acquitted of two counts of attempted grand larceny.

On May 9, 2019, Sorokin was sentenced to 4 to 12 years in prison, plus restitution of over $198,000. She was also ordered to pay a $24,000 fine.

#ICE custody

After serving her sentence, Sorokin was transferred to Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) custody, pending deportation to Germany. She was held at the Orange County Correctional Facility in Goshen, New York.

In October 2021, Sorokin was released from ICE custody, and deported to Germany.

#Media representation

Sorokin's case was highly publicized, and she was featured in several media outlets, including The New York Times, Vanity Fair, and CNN.

In 2022, a Netflix series based on Sorokin's life, "Inventing Anna," was released, starring Anna Chlumsky as a journalist investigating Sorokin's scams.

#After prison

After her release from prison, Sorokin attempted to rebuild her life and reputation.

##Art shows

In 2022, Sorokin announced that she would be showcasing her artwork at a gallery in New York City. The show, titled "Free Anna," featured a series of paintings and sculptures created by Sorokin during her time in prison.

##Non-fungible tokens

In 2022, Sorokin announced that she would be releasing a series of non-fungible tokens (NFTs), featuring her artwork and personal items. The NFTs were sold online, with prices ranging from $1,000 to $10,000.

##Fashion

Sorokin has also attempted to revive her fashion career, partnering with several brands and designers to create clothing and accessories lines.

#Personal life

Sorokin's personal life has been highly publicized, and she has been the subject of several tabloid scandals.

In 2022, Sorokin announced that she was in a relationship with a man she met while in prison.

#Personal life and education

Alan Jackson was born in 1949 in the United Kingdom. He pursued his early education in his hometown before moving to London to study at the London School of Economics (LSE). At LSE, he earned a Bachelor's degree in Economics and later an Master's degree in Accounting. Jackson's educational background in economics and accounting laid the foundation for his future career in business.

##Period at BTR and subsidiaries

During his tenure, he played a crucial role in shaping the company's financial strategy and overseeing its mergers and acquisitions. article:
Hypoxia (medicine)

Hypoxia is a medical condition that occurs when the body or a specific organ or tissue is deprived of adequate oxygen supply. This can be due to various factors such as high altitude, anemia, or respiratory disorders. Hypoxia can be acute or chronic, and its effects can be severe and even life-threatening if left untreated. In this article, we will explore the classification, signs and symptoms, causes, mechanism, diagnosis, prevention, treatment, and outcomes of hypoxia.

# Classification

Hypoxia can be classified in several ways, including by cause, extent, and affected tissues and organs.

## By cause

Hypoxia can be caused by various factors, including ischemia, hypoxemic hypoxia, anemia, and histotoxic hypoxia. Ischemia occurs when the blood flow to a specific organ or tissue is reduced, leading to a decrease in oxygen delivery. Hypoxemic hypoxia occurs when the oxygen levels in the blood are low, often due to respiratory disorders. Anemia occurs when the body has a reduced number of red blood cells or hemoglobin, leading to a decrease in oxygen delivery to tissues. Histotoxic hypoxia occurs when the tissues are poisoned by certain substances, leading to a decrease in oxygen utilization.

## By extent

Hypoxia can be classified as generalized or localized, depending on the extent of the affected area.

### Generalized hypoxia

Generalized hypoxia occurs when the entire body is deprived of adequate oxygen supply. This can be due to various factors such as high altitude, anemia, or respiratory disorders.

### Localized hypoxia

Localized hypoxia occurs when a specific organ or tissue is deprived of adequate oxygen supply. This can be due to various factors such as ischemia, injury, or infection.

### By affected tissues and organs

Hypoxia can affect various tissues and organs, including the brain, cornea, uterus, tumors, and vestibular system.

#### Cerebral hypoxia

Cerebral hypoxia occurs when the brain is deprived of adequate oxygen supply. This can be due to various factors such as stroke, traumatic brain injury, or high altitude.

#### Corneal hypoxia

Corneal hypoxia occurs when the cornea is deprived of adequate oxygen supply. This can be due to various factors such as contact lens use, corneal edema, or corneal injury.

#### Intrauterine hypoxia

Intrauterine hypoxia occurs when the fetus is deprived of adequate oxygen supply during pregnancy. This can be due to various factors such as placental insufficiency, umbilical cord compression, or maternal respiratory disorders.

#### Tumor hypoxia

Tumor hypoxia occurs when the tumor is deprived of adequate oxygen supply. This can be due to various factors such as rapid tumor growth, inadequate blood supply, or anti-angiogenic therapy.

#### Vestibular system

Vestibular hypoxia occurs when the vestibular system is deprived of adequate oxygen supply. This can be due to various factors such as Meniere's disease, benign paroxysmal positional vertigo, or vestibular schwannoma.

# Signs and symptoms

The signs and symptoms of hypoxia can vary depending on the affected tissues and organs. Generalized hypoxia can cause symptoms such as shortness of breath, fatigue, dizziness, and confusion. Localized hypoxia can cause symptoms such as pain, numbness, and weakness in the affected area.

## Complications

Hypoxia can lead to various complications, including organ damage, tissue necrosis, and even death. In severe cases, hypoxia can lead to cardiac arrest, respiratory failure, and coma.

# Causes

Hypoxia can be caused by various factors, including ischemia, hypoxemic hypoxia, anemia, and histotoxic hypoxia.

## Ischemia

Ischemia occurs when the blood flow to a specific organ or tissue is reduced, leading to a decrease in oxygen delivery. This can be due to various factors such as atherosclerosis, thrombosis, or embolism.

## Hypoxemic hypoxia

Hypoxemic hypoxia occurs when the oxygen levels in the blood are low, often due to respiratory disorders. This can be due to various factors such as chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, pneumonia, or cystic fibrosis.

### Carbon monoxide poisoning

Carbon monoxide poisoning occurs when the body is exposed to high levels of carbon monoxide, leading to a decrease in oxygen delivery to tissues.

### Altitude

High altitude can cause hypoxemic hypoxia due to the lower oxygen levels in the air.

### Hypoxic breathing gases

Hypoxic breathing gases can cause hypoxemic hypoxia, often used in medical procedures such as anesthesia.

### Other

Other causes of hypoxemic hypoxia include sleep apnea, obesity hypoventilation syndrome, and neuromuscular disorders.

## Anemia

Anemia occurs when the body has a reduced number of red blood cells or hemoglobin, leading to a decrease in oxygen delivery to tissues. This can be due to various factors such as iron deficiency, vitamin deficiency, or chronic disease.

## Histotoxic hypoxia

Histotoxic hypoxia occurs when the tissues are poisoned by certain substances, leading to a decrease in oxygen utilization. This can be due to various factors such as cyanide poisoning, hydrogen sulfide poisoning, or azide poisoning.

# Mechanism

Hypoxia can be caused by various mechanisms, including physiological responses, acute responses, chronic responses, and pathological responses.

## Physiological responses

The body responds to hypoxia by increasing blood flow to the affected area, increasing oxygen delivery, and increasing anaerobic metabolism.

## Acute

Acute hypoxia can cause a rapid increase in blood flow to the affected area, often accompanied by pain, numbness, and weakness.

## Chronic

Chronic hypoxia can lead to long-term changes in the body, including increased angiogenesis, increased anaerobic metabolism, and changes in gene expression.

## Pathological responses

Hypoxia can lead to pathological responses, including cerebral ischemia, myocardial ischemia, and tumor angiogenesis.

### Cerebral ischemia

Cerebral ischemia occurs when the brain is deprived of adequate oxygen supply, often leading to stroke or traumatic brain injury.

### Myocardial ischemia

Myocardial ischemia occurs when the heart is deprived of adequate oxygen supply, often leading to myocardial infarction or cardiac arrhythmias.

### Tumor angiogenesis

Tumor angiogenesis occurs when the tumor is deprived of adequate oxygen supply, often leading to increased blood vessel growth and tumor progression.

# Diagnosis

The diagnosis of hypoxia can be made using physical examination, history, and various tests.

## Physical examination and history

A physical examination and history can help identify signs and symptoms of hypoxia, such as shortness of breath, fatigue, dizziness, and confusion.

## Tests

Various tests can be used to diagnose hypoxia, including blood tests, imaging tests, and physiological tests.

## Differential diagnosis

A differential diagnosis can help rule out other conditions that may cause similar signs and symptoms, such as anemia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, or cardiac disease.

# Prevention

Prevention of hypoxia can be achieved through various means, including prevention of altitude-induced hypoxia.

## Prevention of altitude-induced hypoxia

Prevention of altitude-induced hypoxia can be achieved through gradual ascent, acclimatization, and use of oxygen therapy.

# Treatment and management

Treatment and management of hypoxia can vary depending on the cause and severity of the condition.

## Treatment of acute and chronic cases

Treatment of acute and chronic cases of hypoxia can include oxygen therapy, medications, and lifestyle changes.

# Outcomes

The outcomes of hypoxia can vary depending on the cause and severity of the condition. In severe cases, hypoxia can lead to organ damage, tissue necrosis, and even death.

# Epidemiology

Hypoxia is a common condition that affects millions of people worldwide. The prevalence of hypoxia varies depending on the population and the underlying cause.

## Silent hypoxia

Silent hypoxia occurs when the body is deprived of adequate oxygen supply without any noticeable signs or symptoms. This can be due to various factors such as high altitude, anemia, or respiratory disorders.

# History

The concept of hypoxia has been known for centuries, with early descriptions of mountain sickness and high-altitude illness.

## Etymology

The term "hypoxia" comes from the Greek words "hypo" meaning "under" and "oxys" meaning "oxygen".

# See also

Other related conditions include anemia, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and cardiac disease.

# Notes

This article provides an overview of hypoxia, including its classification, signs and symptoms, causes, mechanism, diagnosis, prevention, treatment, and outcomes.
